Major averages finished with more losses Tuesday after a late-session rally faded by the close.

The Nasdaq fell 1.8% early, shaved its loss to 0.5% in late trading, but ended 1.3% lower. The S&P 500 gave up 0.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.7%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Monday.

February crude oil lost another 4.2% to settle at $47.93 a barrel, its lowest level since April 2009. Meanwhile, money flowed into bonds again as the yield on the 10-year Treasury note fell 8 basis points to 1.96%.
Mining stocks, tobacco stocks and REITs outperformed, a reflection of a jittery market where institutional selling has been making its presence felt since early December.

Top-rated REITs like Sovran Self Storage (SSS), Omega Healthcare (OHI) and Extra Space Storage (EXR) all scored gains of around 2%. Extra Space broke out from a flat base Tuesday with a 60.66 buy point.

In the stock market today, several names in the IBD 50 gave up their 50-day lines, including NXP Semiconductors (NXPI), F5 Networks (FFIV), SolarWinds (SWI) and Manhattan Associates (MANH), among others. Several others were already below the key support level headed into Tuesday.
Not all news was bad in the IBD 50. Monster Beverage (MNST) gained nearly 3%. It has an investor meeting scheduled for Jan. 13 to give an update on business and operations.

Pssst. I have a two-for-one deal that you absolutely can't refuse.
I'll give you two stocks for every one you own — a 2-for-1 split.
I have to cut the price of the shares I give you in half. So if you own a share worth $100, you get two shares worth $50 each. After all, we can't just arbitrarily double the company's market value.
Here's the deal. The lower share price allows more investors to buy. That will boost the stock price — and the value of your shares. How about it?
Well, you say, let's take a closer look. You in fact might decide that it's actually time to sell your shares and nail your gains.

IBD research shows that one stock split will usually be OK during the early stages of a bull market. But two or more splits during a short period of time — say, within a year or two — may actually signal that the stock has peaked.

Too many stock splits create a flood of supply, which can weigh on share prices if the company has overestimated demand. It's especially true of stocks that have had long, sharp advances near the tail end of a bull market.
Firms that split their shares in a big way, such 3-for-1 or 4-for-1, are especially vulnerable.

Hansen's Natural, now Monster Beverage (MNST), plunged from record high levels shortly after its 4-for-1 split took effect in the week that ended July 14, 2006. The split came only 11 months after an earlier 2-for-1 split in August 2005 and coincided with the market falling into a correction.
Monster, which had hit a high of 52.72 in the week ended July 7, lost more than half its value in just four months.
At the time, Monster boasted best-possible 99 Composite and Earnings Per Share ratings. But stocks' charts often give off sell signals well before their sales growth and profit growth fade.

A stock split is one of many signals that the stock's run may have peaked. According to IBD research, 82% of the stock market's biggest winners didn't split their stocks in the year preceding their biggest price advances.

So shareholders should start looking for sell signals when a company announces that it's splitting its stock. The signals could include a failed breakout from a late-stage base, as Monster had in early August 2006 (1). Monster also plunged below its 10-week moving average in huge trade, another sell signal (2).

Also, if you see repeated new highs in low volume or big downside reversals in heavy trade, it's time to let your shares go and say, "Let's split."Pssst. Stocks opened to broad and breathtaking losses Tuesday, as harsh selling overseas and weakened energy prices took a bite out of investor confidence.
The Nasdaq tumbled 1.1% at the starting bell. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.9% each.
The stock market today opened to heavy trading, with volume up more than 35% on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared with trading at the same time Monday.
The morning's mild economic news was bulldozed by the prevailing influences of energy prices and overseas trade.

The number of unfilled job positions among U.S. employers rose to 4.83 million in October, according to the Labor Department's JOLTS report. The Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey also revised September's unfilled openings lower, to 4.67 million. Hires, job separations and layoffs were all steady during the month, the report said.
Wholesale inventories expanded at a steady rate, growing 0.4% in October, the Commerce Department said. That was just above expectations for a 0.2% increase.
In stocks, Tesla Motors (TSLA) and Monster Beverage (MNST) were down 4% each, dragging on the Nasdaq 100. The Dow strained against 4% losses by Verizon (VZ) and Merck (MRK).

On the IBD 50 list, leaders took even harder hits as Spirit Airlines (SAVE) drilled a 16% loss at the start of trade. Raymond James downgraded the budget airline to market perform, from outperform, and removed its 85 price target. The airline on Monday altered its Q4 margin guidance, based on some pressure seen in industry ticket prices and demand. The loss pulled Spirit away from Monday's high, sending it to a test of 10-week support and 5% below a 74.10 buy point in a cup base.

Ambarella (AMBA) loosed a 6% drop, pointing the maker of chips for GoPro (GPRO) cameras and other devices toward a fourth straight decline. The stock has now dropped 17% from last week's high, but remains above its 10-week line of support and extended from an October rebound.
Oil and natural gas remained stable after diving 4% and 6%, respectively, on Monday. Gold prices jumped more than 2%, to above $1,221 an ounce.

Stocks on the list showing resilience to Tuesday's selling included generic drug maker Akorn (AKRX), which rose 2% in heavy trade. The stock has been holding above 10-week support, building a base with a 45.35 buy point.
San Jose, Calif.-based chip designer Cavium (CAVM) also rose more than 2% in powerful trade. The move hoisted shares 3% past a 56.70 buy point in a cup base.

Stocks rose to new session highs in late trading Wednesday.The Nasdaq rose 0.4% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.1%. Nasdaq volume was running sharply lower from the same time Tuesday. NYSE volume was tracking a touch higher.Freescale Semiconductor (FSL) jumped 7% and cleared the 22.73 buy point of a double-bottom base. On Tuesday, the company said it bought fabless chip company Zenverge for an undisclosed sum. Freescale is seeing strong demand in the automotive market. Sales have grown by double digits after three single-digit quarters in 2013.Sierra Wireless (SWIR) rallied 3% to an all-time high. It's now 30% past a 30.65 buy point from a cup base cleared Nov. 6. The stock has triggered IBD's eight-week hold rule because of its fast advance from the breakout.Avago Technologies (AVGO) climbed 3% to a new high ahead of its earnings after the close. The chip designer is expected to deliver a profit of $1.68 a share, up 89% from a year ago. That would extended its streak of accelerating earnings growth. Avago cleared a 90.98 buy point from a cup base Nov. 18.On the downside, Monster Beverage (MNST) fell 3%, putting it on pace for a third straight loss. On Monday, RBC Capital Markets downgraded Monster to outperform from top pick but raised its price target to 121 from 115. Monster's 19% gain past a 95.03 flat-base buy point has been trimmed to 13%.Aeropostale (ARO), Guess (GES), PVH (PVH) and Synopsys (SNPS) are a few notable companies reporting earnings after the close.

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.

Though Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) plans to launch its highly anticipated cold beverage machine in the fall of 2015, one analyst isn't quite sold on the new platform. A lack of consumer awareness and a far less attractive convenience platform compared with single-cup coffee are two of the main reasons why Longbow Research analyst Alton Stump isn't too optimistic about…

Earnings season is winding down, but some profit reports have caused significant moves among a handful of Weekly Review stocks.In a few cases, results sparked breakouts that have been productive.Thinly traded Multi-Color (LABL) broke out Nov. 7, the day the product labeling company reported a 52% surge in earnings for the September-ended quarter and a 21% increase in sales to $213.0 million. The results beat expectations.The stock is now extended from the 49.93 buy point.Rackspace (RAX) broke out Nov. 11, when it beat third-quarter expectations with a 64% jump in earnings per share.Revenue at the cloud-computing company rose 18% to $459.7 million.Shares soon became extended from the 40.50 buy point of a cup-with-handle base.PetSmart (PETM) on Wednesday cleared a 13-month pattern with a 77.42 buy point. Late Tuesday, PetSmart's Q3 earnings came in at $1.02 a share, up 16% and above the consensus estimate by 8 cents. Sales rose 3% to $1.74 billion, also beating estimates.Another factor fueled the rally: Reports said two private equity firms are considering buying the pet supply retailer and taking it private in a deal that could top $7.5 billion.Monster Beverage (MNST) had already become extended from its breakout when it surged 8% despite a mixed earnings report. Profit topped expectations, but revenue missed views. No matter, the stock extended its advance and is near all-time highs, one of the winners in Your Weekly Review. It's up more than 60% this year.Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) plunged 8% Thursday in huge volume, closing at the 50-day moving average.The company's September-quarter results beat expectations.But news that the company's chief financial officer is leaving seemed to rattle the market.

The IBD 50's four-week winning streak came to an end Friday as the index of leading growth stocks lost 3% for the week. It was a tough week for the broad market, too, as the S&P 500 lost 3.5%. The IBD 50 generally has had a hard time keeping up with the S&P 500 in recent weeks, resulting in a…

Institutional selling is leaving its mark in the market averages and leading stocks. Gains from a rally confirmed in October have diminished for many leaders and a defensive investing posture is warranted. A number of IBD 50 names closed below their 10-week moving averages decisively for the first time Friday. Volume was generally below average, but that can be deceptive…

Monster Beverage (MNST) is primed to see accelerating growth in its fourth quarter and into next year as the energy-drink hotshot benefits from a partnership with Coca-Cola Co. (KO) that should boost its overseas business, according to a report from Wells Fargo Securities' Bonnie Herzog released Friday. The report, in which Herzog reiterated her buy rating on Monster's stock, came…
Stocks finished narrowly mixed Friday after the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 hit record intraday highs, then drifted off in the final hours of trading.
The Nasdaq finished down 0.2%, the Dow climbed 0.1% and the S&P 500 was fractionally higher as volume ran lighter than Thursday, according to preliminary data.
For the week, both the S&P 500 and the Dow scored small gains, while the Nasdaq had a small loss. It was the third straight weekly gain for the big-cap indexes.
In the stock market today, among IBD 50 stocks, 19 were up and 31 were down.

Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) finished down 34% after missing on earnings Thursday evening, announcing its CFO's resignation and a negative accounting change. The stock gapped down below its 200-day moving average and closed at a nine-month low.

Disney (DIS) also followed Thursday's earnings report with a loss, but finished down only 2%, at the top of its daily range. The entertainment giant late Thursday reported earnings in line with views. Revenue grew 7% and edged just past forecasts, but that was the slowest gain in four quarters.

On the upside, Monster Beverage (MNST) surged 8% to a record best in monster volume and is now 14% past a 95.03 buy point from a flat base. The energy drink maker reported Q3 earnings that beat views, though revenue missed. Stocks stumbled in early trading Tuesday, with techs leading the downside action.

Hurt by weakness in software and chip stocks, the Nasdaq dropped 0.9%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. Volume was tracking sharply higher on both exchanges in the stock market today.
Security software stocks were weak following Qualys ' (QLYS) disappointing quarterly sales and outlook.

CyberArk (CYBR) dropped 5% and Palo Alto Networks (PANW) lost more than 1%. Qualys gapped down and plunged 25%. The stock has erased a near 36% gain from a breakout past a 40.84 buy point from a flat base cleared in early February.

Elsewhere, Bloomin' Brands (BLMN) slumped 5% after reporting Q1 earnings that slightly beat views and sales that narrowly missed expectations. The operator of Outback Steakhouse and other restaurants also slightly lowered its sales outlook for the year.

On the upside, Texas Roadhouse (TXRH) gapped up and rallied 6% despite posting mixed quarterly results late Monday. The restaurant operator's earnings beat views, but sales slightly missed. The stock is in a flat base with a 38.52 buy point.

In economic news, the ISM service survey for April unexpectedly rose to 57.8 vs. the Econoday's consensus estimate of 56.5. Markit's service PMI fell to 57.4 from 59.2 in March. Energized by a pact expected to jolt its overseas prospects, Monster Beverage is powered up on Wall Street. Monster's  (MNST) stock price has popped nearly 30% since August 14, when the energy-drink hotshot inked a strategic partnership with beverage giant Coca-Cola (KO). Under the deal, Coke will acquire a 16.7% stake in Monster and get two directors on Monster's…

Top stock mutual fund managers in recent months have been feasting on mostly tech and medical stocks, which were among top gainers in November. The nation's leading funds in the past three months have been pouring money into Apple (AAPL), Yahoo (YHOO), Alibaba (BABA), Baidu (BIDU) and Avago Technologies (AVGO) in their latest reporting periods. Medical big guns Actavis (ACT),…

A nascent market uptrend gained traction Thursday as major averages once again scored strong percentage gains. The bullish session resulted in plenty of strong movers in the new-high list. The Retail/Wholesale-Auto Parts group was one of the day's best performers after O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY) reported strong earnings. The retailer surged to a new high, rising 10.08 to 167.44. It closed…

Monster Beverage (MNST) and Moody's (MCO) cleared buy points Wednesday, leading another short new-highs list. Monster rose 4.04, or 4%, to 96.47 and clearing a 92.87 cup-with-handle buy point. However, volume was just 7% above average, well below the 40% spike that would signal a healthy breakout. Monster soared 30% on Aug. 15 after Coca-Cola (KO) said it would take…

Stocks opened the week with losses and were near session lows about two hours into Monday's session. Another round of disappointing housing data and dampened hopes for more stimulus in China fueled the selling.

The Nasdaq took another hit, falling 1.1%, as it drew closer to its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 lost 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.3$. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking much lower than Friday, but Friday's volume was unusually high due to options expiration.

In the stock market today, Apple (AAPL) added 0.3% on news the company sold more than 10 million iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus units on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. Apple's muted response to the news isn't a big surprise. Good news is often priced into a stock before the news hits, and that appears to be the case with Apple. Shares are up more than 20% after a breakout earlier this year over 82.26.
Monster Beverage (MNST) added 1% in heavy volume. Coca-Cola (KO) recently bought a 16.7% equity stake in the energy drink maker.
Ambarella (AMBA) was among a handful of IBD 50 names that traded higher Monday. Shares rose 0.8%. The stock is extended, but continues to hold near highs after a recent breakout over 33.91.
Meanwhile, in M&A news, German drug firm Merck announced plans to buy chemical maker Sigma-Aldrich (SIAL) for $17 billion. Sigma-Aldrich got a big premium, soaring 34% on the news.

On the downside,Carbo Ceramics (CRR) got hit hard, falling 19%, after the company said sales of its synthetic fracking material fell as customers used more sand. Fracking, or hydraulic fracturing, is the process of extracting natural gas from hard to reach shale rock layers.

In economic news, August existing-home sales fell 1.8% to 5.05 million units. Economists expected a slight increase to 5.18 million units. The new data come on the heels of disappointing housing-start data last week. IBD's Building-Residential/Commercial group lost 1.4% on the news.Stocks opened the week with losses and were near session lows about two hours into Monday's session. Stocks continued to hold slim gains Thursday afternoon.
The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.3% gain, while the S&P 500 was up 0.2%. But the Nasdaq lagged with a 0.1% gain amid weakness in solar and chips.
Volume was tracking lower across the board in the stock market today. Trade was running just a hair lower on the Nasdaq than on the market as a whole.

CDW (CDW) trimmed a 7% gain to 4%. Before the open, the technology products provider delivered Q3 results that cleared analyst projections. The company also raised its dividend, announced a $500 million buyback and said that it was buying a minority stake in Kelway, a U.K.-based IT firm. CDW is in a first-stage cup base with a 33.90 buy point.
LinkedIn (LNKD) bounced 3% after sliding 8% Tuesday. But it's still below a 232.38 buy point from a cup base Monday. LinkedIn reported upbeat Q3 results last week.

Arista Networks (ANET) rallied 3% ahead of its earnings after the close. The networking gear maker is expected to deliver earnings of 28 cents a share, up 56% from a year ago. Sales are expected at $148.27 million, up 46% from a year ago.
On the downside, Advance Auto Parts (AAP) cut losses after finding support at its 50-day line but was still down 2%. It's back above a 139.68 buy point from a flat base.

El Pollo Loco (LOCO), First Solar (FSLR), King Digital Entertainment (KING), Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF), Monster Beverage (MNST), NVIDIA (NVDA), Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) and Walt Disney (DIS) are some notable companies reporting earnings after the close.Stocks continued to hold slim gains Thursday afternoon.The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.3% gain, while the S&P 500 was up 0.2%. Major averages ended mixed Wednesday. The Nasdaq lagged, but not by much, weighed down by weakness in 3D printing, solar, security and online travel stocks.At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 scored new closing highs, rising 0.6% each. The Nasdaq fell less than 0.1%, masking weak performances by many leading growth stocks. Preliminary data showed Nasdaq volume coming in slightly higher than Tuesday. NYSE was very close to Tuesday's level.Gold continued its free fall, dropping another $22, or 1.9% to $1,145.70 an ounce. Crude oil snapped back after recent weakness. It settled at $78.68 a barrel, up 1.9% after a U.S. supply report showed a smaller-than-expected increase in crude stocks.In the stock market today, small-cap Paycom Software (PAYC) was a big winner Wednesday as shares jumped 19%. It gapped up over a 19.34 buy point after reporting strong earnings late Tuesday and issuing a strong sales outlook for the fourth quarter.Meanwhile, about 20 names in the IBD 50 fell 1% or more, but there were some bright spots. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) added 5% after the Dutch supplier of wireless chips said it plans to lure customers by putting a greater emphasis on security for connected devices. NXP is working on a seven-week, cup-shaped base with a buy point of 73.92.Other outperformers in the IBD 50 included chip designer Cavium (CAVM). Shares rose 3%. After a failed breakout over 53.41, Cavium is back above its 10-week moving average as its works on a new base.Another chip designer, Avago Techologies (AVGO), also outperformed, rising nearly 2%. It's working on the right side of a base and is only 4% off its high.Tesla Motors (TSLA) slumped more than 3% ahead of earnings after the close. Reports are also due from Qualcomm (QCOM), Sierra Wireless (SWIR) and SolarCity (SCTY).On Thursday, watch for earnings reports from Akorn (AKRX), Hain Celestial (HAIN), Monster Beverage (MNST) and Skyworks (SWKS).

Managers of leading mutual funds in recent months have continued to stock up on large medical stocks, such as Illumina (ILMN), Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Celgene (CELG), Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ),Allergan (AGN) and Centene (CNC).
The Biotech/Biomed group was ranked No. 1 among 197 industries as of Tuesday. Big-cap biotech and medical stocks hold up better during volatile markets.
Another sector theme being played is semiconductors.
Fabless chipmakers such as Avago Technologies (AVGO), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Ambarella (AMBA) have been top performers. Also acting well is chipmaker Skyworks Solutions (SWKS).

Some food and beverage stocks, such as Keurig Green Mountain Coffee (GMCR), Monster Beverage (MNST), Cal Maine Foods (CALM) and Hain Celestial Group (HAIN), were also favored by the best-performing funds.
IBD spotted 50 top-performing funds that have recently bought Ulta Beauty (ULTA), investing an estimated $298 million.
The $20.4 billion MainStay Large Cap Growth Fund added Ulta to its holdings in its latest reporting period.
Bolingbrook, Ill.-based Ulta is a beauty retailer that provides one-stop shopping beauty products and salon services in America.
The stock is in a 12-month, second-stage base with a small handle. Its failed attempt to break out last week puts it 2% below a 121.53 buy point.
Ulta increased earnings at a healthy double-digit pace the past five quarters. Revenue growth also was robust, in the 20%-plus range, over the same period.
For more in-depth coverage on what's driving Ulta's growth, see Monday's edition of Managing For Success on Page A6.
The first half of October spooked investors with sharp drops across all major stock indexes.
But as in most corrections earlier this year, the market rebounded quickly, resuming its uptrend by late October.
Sell Side
America's top-notch funds lightened up on credit card payment firms Visa (V)and MasterCard (MA) in their latest reporting periods.
But both have rallied the past two weeks, setting or getting near new highs.

Dr Pepper Snapple Group has been a sweet deal to investors who have bought shares of the drink maker this year. Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) stock is up 25% so far, outpacing the S&P 500's 7% gain. Also, the firm pays a 2.7% dividend at the current share price, well above the S&P average 1.9%. Dr Pepper Snapple, which traces…
Stock futures ladled out moderate losses ahead of Friday's open, as an uptick in May producer prices added to the inflation pressure on the Federal Reserve.
Dow futures slipped 39.4 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 15.3 points and S&P 500 futures were down 5.4 points.

The stock market today heads into Friday with the Nasdaq up 0.3% this week and the S&P 500 ahead 0.8%. The Nasdaq continued to find support at its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 slipped below that level late last week, but retook support on Wednesday. A significant change in the eurozone's debt standoff with Greece, or clarity regarding a possible rate increase by the Federal Reserve, could help urge indexes out of their months-long limits. But until the market challenges the high or lows of its recent range, investors must stay prepared for a shift in either direction.

In economic news, prices paid to producers rose 0.5% in May, the Labor Department reported, the largest increase since at least December. The gain reversed April's 0.4% decline, and it topped analyst expectations for a 0.4% increase. The core Producer Price Index, minus energy and food, edged up 0.1% vs. a 0.2% slip in April and in line with expectations.
The University of Michigan is slated to release its initial June consumer sentiment estimate at 10 a.m. ET.

Stock action showedTwitter (TWTR) perking up 3% after announcing Chief Executive Dick Costolo will step down July 1. Twitter co-founder and Chairman Jack Dorsey will serve as interim CEO during a search for a new CEO. Dorsey said he would take no compensation for the position until later in the year. The stock has been unable to exit a consolidation begun shortly after its November 2013 IPO. It ended Thursday 52% below its Dec. 27 high.

Connecticut-based biotech Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped more than 2% in premarket action. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since December and has been struggling to regain its 10-week moving average since early May.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Synaptics (SYNA) rose 2% before the open. The company announced Thursday it had reached a milestone, with shipments of fingerprint sensors now topping 200 million units. The sensors are used in smartphones, tablets and notebook computers. The stock has been hovering just below a June 3 high, ending Thursday almost 7% above a 91.33 buy point.

Overseas, markets across Asia ended higher, led by a 1.4% jump by Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The Shanghai Composite rose 0.9% to end the week up 2.8%. The Hang Seng ended up a fraction for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.1% Friday to end the week effectively flat.
Europe's top indexes were also tracking toward flat finishes for the week, with the FTSE 100 in London, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris all showing moderate losses near midday.

The dollar continued to gain ground, keeping downward pressure on stocks and commodity prices. Oil and gold traded lower, with West Texas Intermediate futures holding just above $60 per barrel and the August gold contract trading at $1,179.20 an ounce. For the week, oil was up not quite 2%. Gold was about 1% higher than last Friday's settle price.
Stocks pounded out healthy gains in early trade Friday.
The Nasdaq jumped 0.6%. The S&P 500 grabbed a 0.4% gain and the Dow Jones industrial average popped 0.3%.
Volume on the stock market today got a boost from options expiration. Trade surged 52% on the Nasdaq and soared 166% on the NYSE compared with action at the same time Thursday.

Economic news continued to roll out, with the Treasury Department reporting foreign investors sold a net $18.7 billion in U.S. stocks and other vehicles in June. The long-term Treasury International Capital flow report downwardly revised its May number to $18.6 billion. June's adjusted number, which estimates unrecorded principal payments to foreigners on U.S. asset-backed securities and other factors, showed sales of $30.2 billion.

Factory output ratcheted up 0.4% in July, the Federal Reserve said, even with June's upwardly revised reading and slightly above the 0.3% gain expected by economists. Capacity utilization eked up to 79.2% vs. June's 79.1 level and in line with expectations.

Consumer confidence ebbed in August, with the University of Michigan's preliminary reading on its Consumer Sentiment Survey slipping to 79.2, down from 81.8 in July. Analysts consensus pointed to a reading of 82.3.

In stocks, Monster Beverage (MNST) staked out the morning's high road, rocketing 29% higher on a partnership deal with Coca-Cola (KO) late Thursday. The pact includes Coke making a $2.1 billion payment and handing over its energy drink portfolio, including tasty names like Full Throttle and Burn. Monster had been consolidating since February. Friday's move sent shares above their April 2012 high. Coke rose 2%.

Applied Materials (AMAT) jumped 5% after reporting fiscal third-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings narrowly topped expectations. Revenue growth stopped short of estimates. But new orders and gross margins surged, and management gave in-line guidance for the rest of the year.
The chip designer is in the fourth week of a shallow consolidation.
The open was almost unanimously positive among IBD 50 stocks, with all but a few rising at the starting bell.

Vipshop Holdings (VIPS) stroked out a 3% gain, moving to just below its high mark notched on Wednesday. The China-based online retailer is extended above a 175.26 buy point in a late-stage, cup-with-handle base.Stocks pounded out healthy gains in early trade Friday.The Nasdaq jumped 0.6%. Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Huntington is trading below a 136.55 buy point in a long cup-with-handle base.Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. Stocks held near their session highs Monday afternoon, thanks to easing geopolitical tension, merger news and better-than-expected housing data.

The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 1% gain. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq climbed 0.9% and the S&P 500 rose 0.8%. Turnover was again running lower on both major exchanges in the stock market today. Friday was an options expiration day, which makes for a tough volume comparison.

Lannett (LCI) gapped up and rallied 9% after giving an upbeat outlook. The generic-drug maker said it expects fiscal Q4 sales to come in at $81 million and pegged earnings at 60 cents to 64 cents a share. Both are above current views calling for earnings of 41 cents a share and revenue of $71.16 million. Lannett is close to potential resistance at its 50-day line.

58.com (WUBA) climbed 6% in fast trade, clearing short-term resistance at the 50 level. The stock, which recently found support at its 10-week line, has formed a cup base within a larger pattern. Its buy point is at 57.60. The company will report Q2 earnings Thursday before the market open. Profit is expected at 8 cents a share, up 33% from a year ago.

AerCap Holdings (AER) cruised up nearly 4% to an all-time high. It cleared a 48.91 buy point from a flat base in volume that was tracking more than double its average pace. The Dutch aircraft leasing company was profiled in Stock Spotlight last week.

Leaders down in volume were few, but Monster Energy (MNST) fell 4% in fast trade. Early gains faded into losses late Friday morning amid reports of fighting between Ukraine and Russia. But the major indexes stuck to solid gains so far for the week.
The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 0.4%, hamstrung by Merck's (MRK) 1% loss. The S&P 500 shed 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%.

The stock market today set out seeming largely unswayed by mixed early news and data reports. But early optimism eroded, and options expirations drove volume higher. Late morning trade remained up 92% on the NYSE and 20% higher on the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time Thursday.

Monster Beverage (MNST) (up 30%), Applied Materials (AMAT) (up 5%) and Kinder Morgan (KMI) (up 4%) continued to hold the top spots on the S&P 500. Nordstrom (JWN) posted the index's largest loss, gapping down to a 4% loss in heavy trade after reporting results late Thursday.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) gained 3% to move to the head of the IBD 50 list. Shares had initially punched up 4%, putting the stock back above its 50-day line. The stock had faded more than 8% below a 156.44 cup-with-handle buy point, negating the breakout. If it retakes that buy point in solid trade it remains a valid entry.

Lithia Motors (LAD) dropped 3% in fast trade, slipping back to retest its 50-day moving average. The number of stocks in Your Weekly Review has gotten smaller, a symptom of a weakening general market.
Usually, this screen of top-rated stocks exceeds 120 companies. But a week ago, it had 90 and today ended up with about 100.
The shrinking Weekly Review tends to happen when the market has weakened to such a point that fewer stocks can earn the necessary requirements of the screen.
Primarily, those requirements are Earnings Per Share and Relative Price Strength Ratings of 85 or higher. Naturally, when growth stocks are slumping, their relative price performance will suffer.
While that leaves fewer quality stocks for investors to choose from, it also serves a good purpose by purging the weaker choices.

For example, Nautilus (NLS) was in last week's Weekly Review, but it has dropped from today's list after the maker of fitness equipment plunged below the 10-week moving average in heavy trading and triggered the 8% sell rule.
Commscope (COMM) is another stock that no longer makes the cut. Its breakout past a 25.90 buy point has failed and shares are now trading below the long-term 200-day moving average.
Because the screen works as a filtering system, the ones left on Weekly Review should be considered to be of higher quality. That makes the survivors better qualified for watch lists.
Among the stocks still upright are some medical leaders forming bases, such as Akorn (AKRX) and Gilead Sciences (GILD).
Large-capitalization companies such as Apple (AAPL) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) are shaping fine bases and deserve to be studied closer.

Monster Beverage (MNST) just broke out past a 92.87 buy point and remains in buy range. Volume was lackluster Wednesday as the stock cleared the entry, which is a reason to be suspicious about the move.The number of stocks in Your Weekly Review has gotten smaller, a symptom of a weakening general market.Usually, this screen of top-rated stocks exceeds 120 companies. Monster (MNST) gapped up and rocketed 21.84, or 31%, to 93.49 in monster volume, shooting past a 75.73 buy point. Coca-Cola made its second caffeine-rich strategic alliance this year, announcing a big stake late Thursday in Monster Beverage, sending the energy drink maker's shares soaring to record highs. Coke (KO) will pay $2.15 billion for a 16.7% stake in Monster Beverage (MNST) and two seats on the energy drink specialist's board. Coke will give its energy drink brands like Full…
Stocks pared losses Friday after a harsh reminder that Ukraine, even when it goes to the back burner for a while, remains an area of concern for the market.
Two days after the Nasdaq flashed a sign of strength, stocks reversed early gains, but battled back to end mixed and mostly unchanged.

At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%, weighed down by General Electric (GE) and Visa (V). The S&P 500 closed fractionally lower and the Nasdaq rallied 0.3%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Thursday as options expired.
For the week, the Nasdaq rose 2.2%; the S&P 500 rallied 1.2% and the Dow gained 0.7%.

In the stock market today, Monster Beverage (MNST) vaulted 30% on news Coca-Cola (KO) is buying a 17% stake in the energy drink maker for $2.15 billion. Amid slumping soft-drink sales, Coke has been expanding its arsenal. It recently bought a stake in Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) to market a Keurig cold-beverage maker. In May, Coke upped its stake in Keurig to 16%.

Elsewhere, Leaderboard nameFleetCor Technologies (FLT) added to recent gains, rising 1.5%. Earlier this week, the market cheered news it was acquiring e-payments firm Comdata for $3.45 billion. FleetCor is a provider of fuel cards and workforce payment products.

Sierra Wireless (SWIR) gained ground for the seventh time in eight sessions, rising 3%. It's been consolidating gains since January and is only 11% off its all-time high. Full-year earnings are seen rising 74% this year, with growth accelerating in 2015, up 110%.
Gilead Sciences (GILD) rose 3% on news it won a dispute with Roche (RHHBY) over rights to its blockbuster hepatitis C drug Sovaldi.
On the downside, Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillard's (DDS) led IBD's Retail-Department Stores group to a decline of nearly 5%.

At first glance, flagging soft drink sales might be a reason to shun Dow component Coca-Cola. But recent strategic initiatives show that the firm isn't ready to quit yet.

Carbonated beverages still account for the lion's share of sales volume at Coca-Cola (KO), but with soda consumption waning in North America, Coke has branched out into juices, bottled water, Powerade and energy drinks.

Shares gapped up nearly 2% on Aug. 15 after Coke announced plans to acquire a 17% stake in Monster Beverage (MNST) for about $2 billion. Monster has a big share of the U.S. energy drink market. It's also been increasing its share overseas. Sales in 2013 totaled $2.25 billion, up 9% from 2012. As part of the deal, Monster will transfer its non-energy brands, including Hansen's Natural and Peace Tea, to Coke.

In February, Coke acquired a 10% stake in Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) for $1.25 billion. A few months later, it increased its stake to 16%. The Keurig Cold system is expected to launch next year and will offer at-home carbonation of soft drinks without a CO2 cartridge.
Last week, Keurig added two varieties of Coke's Honest Tea K-Cups for its hot brewing machines.

When Coke reported second-quarter earnings in July, profit rose 2% from a year ago, but sales fell 1% to $12.57 billion, its sixth straight quarter of declining sales growth. Beverage volumes rose 3% worldwide while soda volumes rose 2%. In the first quarter, soda volumes fell for the first time since 1999. In North America, soda volumes were flat.
Annual earnings growth is expected to be flat this year at $2.08 a share, with growth ramping up in 2015, rising 7% to $2.22.

Coke has a dividend growth rate of 8%. It pays a quarterly dividend of 30.5 cents, giving it an annual yield of 2.9%.At first glance, flagging soft drink sales might be a reason to shun Dow component Coca-Cola. Mild to moderate growth is expected for Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) as the coffee and tea seller counts its earnings in between holiday gift-buying seasons.

The Waterbury, Vt.-based firm famed for its single-serve K-Cups is expected to earn 95 cents a share, a 2.2% gain from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is forecast to grow 4.3% to $1.05 billion when it reports its fiscal Q2 earnings Wednesday.

With the Christmas shopping season behind Keurig and the spring gift-buying season for Mother's Day, Father's Day and graduations approaching in the current quarter ending June 30, analysts aren't looking for spectacular gains from the first three months of the calendar year.
"We're not expecting a huge bump up at the moment," said Marc Riddick, a senior analyst at Williams Capital Group. "It's not really what I'd call a gifting season."

Instead, the $1.25 billion equity investment that Coca-Cola (KO) made in Keurig is expected to give the coffee-product maker a firm foothold in the cold-beverage market — and on a global scale. Keurig is looking overseas to Australia, South Korea and Sweden to expand its brand.
Keurig shares closed down 1.9% to 90.61 Friday.

As for Keurig's competitors, potential or real, SodaStream (SODA) has been the subject of merger rumors, including a merger with Starbucks (SBUX). SodaStream shares are down 15% so far this year to 42.21.

Monster Beverage (MNST) reports earnings Thursday and is expected to earn 49 cents a share, up 32.4% from a year earlier. Revenue is expected to post a 12.3% gain to $543.6 million. Stocks rose Friday after the European Central Bank hinted at new stimulus measures to boost inflation. But the major averages ended off intraday highs.

The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.5%, and the S&P 500 was up 0.4%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, rising 16% on the NYSE and falling 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday, according to preliminary figures.
European Central Bank head Mario Draghi suggested that the ECB will introduce new stimulus measures at its Dec. 3 meeting.
Retailers, medical and apparel stocks led the upside, while data storage, energy and steel stocks underperformed.

Nike (NKE) led the Dow and the IBD 50, jumping 5% in heavy volume after announcing a 2-for-1 stock split, share buyback and a dividend increase late Thursday. The stock is well extended past a 117.82 buy point but has found support at the 50-day moving average.

Alaska Air (ALK) was also among the best-performing IBD 50 stocks. The regional airline climbed nearly 3%, in line with oil's plunge below $40 a barrel, as it nears an 82.88 buy point of a flat base. Hawaiian Holdings (HA) also rose nearly 3%. The carrier is just 1% off an all-time high and well out of buying range.

Crucially, a stock will often give you a sell signal so clear that you can only ignore it at your peril.Consider the failure of a late-stage base as a stock's way of saying it's done.Imagine what you risk by extending the stock some leeway. Maybe you bought the stock as it formed that late-stage base.Why would you do such a thing? A late pattern is itself a flaw. Well, maybe the base was especially tight, and the price-volume action looked ideal. Or the group was hot.But failure is failure. And failing from a late-stage base suggests that there's lots of room on the downside after a long run-up.Perhaps yours was a long-held position. So you have a bigger profit cushion than recent buyers. So what? That you have "some room" when the stock starts misbehaving is no reason to surrender a substantial portion of your hard-fought gains.Monster Beverage's (MNST) story is classic. Maybe you bought the stock at 27.47 (adjusted for a 2-for-1 split) as it broke out from an early-stage flat base in January 2011. (See a long-term weekly chart.) It was the latest in a string of tight bases that was, collectively, a long base-on-base pattern.The next base appeared in the seven weeks through the week ended Aug. 19, 2011. (1) A five-week flat base appearing a few months later (2) was tighter — and, as a base-on-base to the August pattern, kept the base count relatively low.From this latter pattern, the stock soared 72% to 83.96, with an ugly downside reversal in the week ended May 4, 2012. (3)That reversal, along with the highest volume of the move, was itself a major sell signal.The sideways-to-higher drift seen in the ensuing seven weeks was the stock's attempt to build another base. The attempt was poor, the pattern hard to define — except that it was a late-stage structure.The final straw appeared in late June 2012, with the stock slicing its 10-week line in monster volume. (4) Why might you have given Monster some room after such a show of weakness? Perhaps because the stock ended the week in the upper half of that trading range? Well, that was, strictly speaking, an upside reversal.But you had "Monster" profits in this stock, which you started accumulating either at 19.15 or at 27.47. And it was failing from a late-stage base. Enough said.

The Nasdaq led a market rally Thursday with another 52-week high as buyers continued to have the upper hand.

At the close, the tech-heavy index added 0.6% while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.5% each. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in slightly lower than Wednesday's levels.

In a speech in front of the Senate Banking Committee, Fed chief Janet Yellen acknowledged recent softness in economic data and repeated recent Fed assurances that its pullback in stimulus "is not on a preset course."

In the stock market today, Baidu (BIDU) rose nearly 4% on strong earnings. Sales growth accelerated for the third straight quarter, rising 55% to $1.57 billion, but flat to single-digit earnings growth over the past three quarters gives pause. Still, the company ended 2013 with with more than 100 million active mobile customers.

Generic drugmaker Mylan (MYL) surged 9% on strong earnings. The stock continues to perform well after a recent flat-base breakout in January over 44.83. Its industry group — Medical-Generic Drugs — has been a hotbed of acquisition activity lately. CEO Heather Bresch said the company is "well poised for a transaction."

China-based Autohome (ATHM) hit an all-time high, rising 13%, after Monday's nasty reversal. Earlier this week, the company reported a 171% surge in quarterly profit with sales up 79% to $63.8 million. The company is an online destination for car buyers in China, currently the world's largest car market by sales volume of new automobiles.

On the downside, Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) slumped 9%. Its recent breakout over 67.91 is going nowhere fast. Its two-day decline now stands at 13% after noted short seller Citron Research issued another negative report on the company. Shares of the drugmaker surged nearly 10% on Feb. 18 ahead of its earnings report. The company reported another quarter of solid growth on Wednesday.

While day-to-day price fluctuations are hard to explain, long-term moves in a stock happen for a reason. There's usually some driving force that fuels dramatic moves in a company's shares."It takes something new to produce a startling advance in the price of a stock," wrote IBD founder and Chairman William O'Neil in the investment classic "How to Make Money in Stocks."So make sure that there's some kind of positive catalyst behind a company that can send its shares sharply higher. This is essentially the idea behind the "N" in IBD's CAN SLIM investment model, which stands for "new."Something new could be a revolutionary new product or service. Don't just look for small improvements, but factors that are game changers. It could also be new management, such as a savvy CEO from another company. New can also refer to something that shakes up the industry.In addition, the new could simply be a new high in its stock price following a breakout.Practically all of the major stock market winners over time had one or more new factors as they made their stellar runs.America Online (AOL) gave millions of consumers their first taste of the Internet and online communities. Monster Beverage (MNST) hit it big with its line of Monster Energy drinks. Under the leadership of the late Steve Jobs, Apple (AAPL) changed the way people bought and listened to music. The Cupertino, Calif.-based company followed suit with breakthrough products such as the iPhone and iPad.In IBD, investors can find plenty of features on companies with innovative new products and services, new management and new industry developments. Read The New America , Internet & Technology page , IBD Industry Themes  and Stock Spotlight Analysis, among others.3D Systems (DDD) was a big winner in 2013, as shares surged 161%. The Rock Hills, S.C.-based firm isn't really new, having started in 1986, nor is 3D printing. But the industry really started taking off in 2013 as more companies recognized the benefits of 3D printing. Plus, 3D Systems and rivals such as Stratasys (SSYS) and ExOne (XONE) continued to innovate with new types of printers.Volatile action in 3D Systems made it tough to trade. But the stock went on a tear in the week ended Oct. 11 as it bounced off its 10-week moving average  (1).

Stocks weakened at the starting bell Thursday, as investors compounded Wednesday's losses while awaiting Senate testimony from the Federal Reserve chief.X The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.3% and the S&P 500 shed 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite clung to a fractional gain.Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) racked up the heaviest early declines on the Dow, off more than 1% each. Monster Beverage (MNST) posted the heaviest loss among Nasdaq 100 stocks, and veterinary supplies distributor Patterson (PDCO) dropped 21% — the worst decline among S&P 500 stocks.A sell-off begun just after 2 p.m. Wednesday hauled all three major indexes to steep losses and left the Dow and the S&P 500 back below their 50-day moving averages.The result put the Nasdaq down 1.9% for February, in its first monthly decline since June. The Dow suffered a 4.3% loss for the month, its first slip since March 2017 and its worst month since January 2016. The S&P 500 ended down 3.9%, also its worst decline since January 2016.Get IBD's Market Prep And Tech Report Newsletters — For Free!The U.S. sell-off rippled into Japan and Europe, although markets in China rebounded after two days of pronounced selling. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dived 1.6%, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng index popped 0.7%.In Europe, Frankfurt's DAX tanked 1.4% and the CAC-40 in Paris dropped 0.8%. London's FTSE 100 was down 0.7% in afternoon trade.Thursday's heavy dose of economic news may be dominated by the Federal Reserve Chief Jerome Powell, as he steps before the Senate Banking Committee for his second day of testimony this week. Markets moved lower following Powell's comments before the House on Tuesday, although the overall tenor of the Fed chief's tone was positive.But an early economic release from the Commerce Department showed growth in the department's PCE Price Index inflation gauge slowed sharply, up 0.1%, vs. a 0.4% gain in December and well below the consensus target for a 0.4% gain. Core prices rose 0.2%, down from December's 0.3% advance and below views for a 0.3% rise.The pace of spending meanwhile doubled to 0.4%, topping expectations for a steady reading of 0.2%. The report also showed personal income held steady in January, up 0.4% vs. consensus views for a 0.3% advance.First-time unemployment claims dipped for a second straight week, to 210,000 for the week ended Feb. 24. Consensus estimates called for an increase to 230,000 claims.Manufacturing indexes from Markit and the Institute Of Supply Management are due out at 9:45 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Automakers also are expected to unveil February sale totals throughout the session.Among the morning's biggest earnings-related gains, Hostess Brands (TWNK) jumped 11% and Anheuser Busch (BUD) climbed 4%. Software developer Box (BOX) tumbled 16% after its fourth-quarter report, and Victoria's Secret owner L Brands (LB) slipped 11% as investors reacted to weak first-quarter guidance.Netflix (NFLX) reversed its opening gain and slipped 0.1%, despite announcing a deal with U.K.-based satellite broadcaster Sky that will distribute Netflix streaming content via the Sky Q service to homes in England and Ireland. Netflix shares are extended following a January breakout.Best Buy rose 1% after scoring a big win on its fourth-quarter earnings line. Revenue also topped expectations, although first-quarter earnings guidance was weak. The stock has been holding support at its 10-week moving average in the fifth week of a possible base pattern.Salesforce.com rose 4% at Thursday's open, leading the S&P 500 after its late-Wednesday report showed fourth-quarter earnings and revenue, and full-year profit guidance, above analyst estimates. But guidance for billings in the current quarter was below expectations, possibly tempering some early gains.Footwear maker Crocs (CROX) rebounded nearly 8%, as Piper Jaffray raised its rating on the stock to overweight, from neutral. Crocs shares had sold off 13%, cutting their 10-week moving average in heavy volume, on Wednesday, following mixed fourth-quarter results.Monster Beverage dropped 11% as its fourth-quarter results came up short of analyst targets. The Corona, Calif.-based company saw strong single-digit growth in energy drink sales, but said results were hurt by customer reductions in overseas inventory. The stock has been struggling to retake and hold 10-week support since the start of February.Other Market-Related News For Thursday:The Big Picture: Investors Face These Six Market RisksDow Plunges 380 Points As Stocks End This Remarkable Win StreakInflation Boogeyman Returns; Splunk, VMware, Best Buy: Action PlanWhy Did This 99 Composite Rating Stock Dive And Rebound?How Do you Spot  A Major Market Top? Energy-drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST) on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings and sales that missed estimates after the market close.X Estimates: Earnings per share of 37 cents, with revenue of $842 million.Results: EPS up 17.5% to 35 cents, on net sales up 7.5% to $810.4 million.The company said net sales during the quarter were "adversely affected by inventory reductions by certain of our international distributors."Stock: Shares plunged 8% after hours on the stock market today. Coca-Cola (KO), which in 2015 completed a deal to take a 16.7% stake in Monster and handle international distribution for the company, was up 0.7%.IBD'S TAKE: Cowen has cited "emerging access to legal cannabis" as an investment risk for Monster. Even as investors in the cannabis industry try to get in on the ground floor, investing in the space in the U.S. can be tricky.Monster saw sales gains in the U.S. through last year, and the company stands to benefit from easier year-over-year comparisons for much of this year, Cowen analyst Vivien Azer wrote in a research note in January.Monster's drinks also tend to sell at a big discount to rival Red Bull, something Cowen analysts believe could also be helping the company.The company also continues to expand internationally, with China seen as among the bigger opportunities. Monster has begun working with the English Premier Soccer League and tried to have more of a presence in esports — both of which are popular in the nation, Cowen analysts have noted.And as McDonald's (MCD), Starbucks (SBUX) and convenience stores battle over customers' caffeine dependency, Monster has also bulked up on its own coffee drinks: Caffe Monster — which the company is in the process of launching in the U.S. — Java Monster, Espresso Monster and others.Shares of McDonald's rose 0.2% after-hours, while Starbucks edged up .01%.YOU MIGHT BE INTERESTED IN:Here's How McDonald's Will Invest $6 Billion In The U.S. Through 2020Cashless Stores And Cryptocurrency: What Is Starbucks Up To?Monster Beverage Tumbles Below Buy Point On Low-Energy Earnings

Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) plans to expand its offerings into the types of beverages SodaStream (SODA) machines make, putting the two companies on a potential collision course as consumers turn to more types of beverages.

Soda consumption is on the decline in the U.S., while energy drinks, coffees and teas are rising in popularity. Meanwhile, the interest in 3D printer makers 3D Systems (DDD) and Stratasys (SSYS) points to the growing desire to have more personalized products.
Green Mountain's single-serve Keurig coffee brewers and SodaStream's soda makers might at first glance offer two different beverage experiences.

But Keurig machines can also brew Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) flavored iced tea, hot apple cider or Swiss Miss hot chocolate. And Green Mountain hinted that more changes are on the horizon on its earnings conference call Wednesday.
CEO Brian Kelley said the company sees a "strong opportunity to pursue adjacencies to our current business," such as juices, carbonated beverages, sports drinks and enhanced waters.
That would overlap more with SodaStream's machines, which can make carbonated colas, energy drinks, lemonade and iced teas. Users can also mix flavors together to make unique beverages.
SodaStream is looking to expand its offerings too. The company recently signed deals to offer Country Time Lemonade and Kool Aid.
Green Mountain shares fell 1.6% in the stock market today, after dropping 6% after hours on Wednesday's disappointing Q3 report. SodaStream shares were up less than 1%.
Soda consumption in 2012 fell for the eighth straight year to the lowest levels since 1996, according to Beverage Digest. But Americans are still staying hydrated.
Sales of Monster Beverage's (MNST) energy drinks as well as Coca-Cola's (KO) and Pepsico.'s (PEP) bottled water have been on the uptick.

Monster is expected to report an 8.5% rise in earnings to 64 cents per share, when it reports results after the close Thursday. Sales are seen rising 9% to $646 million. An Israeli newspaper reported Thursday that PepsiCo (PEP) was in talks to buy SodaStream (SODA), but the snack and beverage giant denied the reports. Carbonated beverage makers have been looking to expand business as soda consumption continues to fall in the U.S. According to The Calcalist, an Israeli financial newspaper, Pepsi made an offer to buy SodaStream, an Israeli in-home…
New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's controversial ban on sales of soft drinks and other sugary drinks didn't clear the courts. But Americans continue to sip fewer and fewer sodas on their own.
In 2012 soda sales volume declined 1.2% to 9.17 billion cases, according to industry analyst Beverage Digest. That's the lowest level since 1996. Soda consumption dipped 0.5% in 2010 and 1% in 2011.

Coca-Cola (KO) shares rose 8 cents to 40.12 on the stock market today, the highest close since early August. PepsiCo (PEP) shares fell 1% after spiking more than 3% to a 5-year high on Friday on news that activist investor Nelson Peltz had taken a stake. Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) shares fell 0.1% after hitting a record high intraday.
While traditional carbonated beverages like Coke, Pepsi and Sprite are on the decline, energy drink consumption is expanding.
Not including energy drinks like Monster Energy (MNST) and Red Bull, total carbonated beverage consumption would be down 1.7% on the year.
Monster, which changed its name from Hanson's Natural in early 2012, rose rapidly in 2011 and 2012, closing at an all time high of 78.72 in June as Americans were thirsty for energy boosters.
But shares have tumbled since mid-2012 amid health concerns and possible restrictions on sales. They fell 12 cents to 48.38 on Monday.

Beverage companies are still gaining market share as they try to branch out of the carbonated beverage bubble. As well as its namesake soda, Coke offers Dasani branded bottled water, Odwalla natural juices and Vitamin Water enhanced flavored water. Pepsi sells Gatorade sports drinks, Ocean Spray juices, Aquafina water, Lipton teas and SoBe Lifewater flavored non-carbonated beverages. Pepsi also owns the Frito-Lay snack brand.
Overall beverage sales rose 1%, Beverage Digest reported.
But Pepsi's beverage market share continues to shrink, contracting 0.4% in 2012. Coke and Dr Pepper Snapple's market shares both grew 0.1%.

Do you want to sell stocks short with success? And do you already know IBD's CAN SLIM system for selecting great stocks on the long side? If you answer "yes" to both questions, then you must understand this about shorting: Focus your analysis on what the stock is doing on the chart right now, not what you think is happening…

Sometimes great stocks approaching their peaks flash too many sell signs to ignore. Sometimes they flash subtle ones.One such sign is a fast series of big stock splits. Many investors see splits bullishly. Companies use stock splits to lower share prices. But you should treat them with caution.Theoretically, lower prices mean more demand. A 2-for-1 split halves the price of a stock from $100 to $50 while doubling the number of shares outstanding. Investors who previously couldn't afford a share might now be tempted. (Companies can effect splits in ratios of up to 10-to-1 or more.) But a split does not change the current value of the company in any way.There are reasons that companies like Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG) and  Priceline.com (PCLN) have share prices of $439 to $820. (The grandpappy of the stock split resistance is Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA), with its Class A share price now topping $160,000.)These stocks attract investors willing to pay for quality. That might narrow the potential audience, but it tends to increase the smart-money sponsors that are backing the stock. Stock splits attract smaller investors. In effect, they change the neighborhood.To be sure, early stock splits are often not a problem.Stocks can and often do move higher after initial splits — particularly when they happen early in a bull market. But problems occur when companies enact multiple big splits — say, a 2-for-1 and a 3-for-1 — in a one- to two-year period.This floods the market with a company's shares. IBD research shows a stock will often reach a price peak around its second or third split. Research also shows that only 18% of history's biggest winners had even a single stock split in the year preceding the start of their run.One good example of a hot stock tripping on a stock split is  Monster Beverage (MNST), once named Hansen Natural. Monster, one of the original energy drink success stories, jetted more than 4,000% from 2003 to 2006.The company enacted its first stock split in August 2005 (1) , just a month after the stock first touched $100 per share (chart is split-adjusted). The stock's response shows why a single stock split, like most sell signals, is not a sign to cut and run.Just after the split, Monster shares dropped through their 10-week line in heavy trade, but stopped a short distance below the line. The stock formed a new base, then broke out and moved higher.The second, truly monster 4-to-1 split, occurred just after the stock punched through the 210 pre-adjusted price level in July 2006. (2) Shares responded immediately with a pullback to the 10-week line in heavy trade. Monster dived a few weeks later en route to a 53% correction.
The managers of the $782 million Thornburg Core Growth Fund are jugglers.
They blend and balance three types of growth stocks into their portfolio: mature industry leaders, consistent growers and emerging growers.

That approach helped these managers extend their successful investing streak. Their fund was up 21.82% this year through Aug. 30. That topped 96% of their large-cap growth rivals, averaging 15.56%, as tracked by Morningstar Inc. The S&P 500 was up 16.15%.
The fund is outperforming 98% of its peers over the past three years and 84% of its peer group over the past five years.
Co-manager Greg Dunn, 37 years old, spoke with IBD from his office in Santa Fe, N.M.

IBD: Your fund has some interesting features. You run a concentrated portfolio. You buy stocks when they're trading at a discount. You can invest in stocks of any size. Tell me what each trait contributes.

Dunn: Concentration lets us focus on our best ideas. We tend to hold 40 to 55 stocks. It varies depending on whether we're finding a lot of opportunities and the risk profile of each investment. We're around 50 now.
We consider our price target on each stock a representation of intrinsic value. And we don't own a stock unless we believe there is upside from the current price. So we always buy at a discount.

Size flexibility reflects our three-basket structure. Our emerging-growth leaders tend to be more aggressive stocks, smaller and faster growing. They're generally sitting in front of a large opportunity.
The second basket, our growth industry leaders, tends to be midcap or large caps. These have leadership positions. They're more mature companies.

The third basket holds our consistent growers. They add a little defensive nature to the portfolio. They tend to have a good element of visibility. They often have a subscription model or recurring revenue and good earnings visibility.
IBD: What sort of an edge do you get from your three-basket tack?

Dunn: The three baskets add diversification. They let us balance risk from more conservative to more aggressive growth stocks. Stocks perform differently in different markets. This lets us aim for good performance throughout investment cycles.
IBD: How do you divvy your cash among the three baskets?
Dunn: We want about 33% in each.
IBD: You make bottom-up investment decisions. But sector weights reflect where you tend to look for leaders. Why is software your largest sector currently?
Dunn: There's a lot of innovation and change there. Part of our weighting is exposure to SaaS — software as a service. It is disruptive to software on the premises. Lower cost. Faster upgrade cycles.
Another reason is that we like software companies that have expertise serving a specific vertical niche.

Guidewire Software (GWRE), for example, developed a software platform for property and casualty insurers. The core platform covers policy claims and billing systems. For years the software that insurers used was in-house, antiquated, inflexible and expensive to maintain. Guidewire's works much better. Its value proposition is really strong. And it is addressing a big market, which is bigger than $10 billion. Their share is less than 5%. But they're starting to win big deals that validate them within the industry.
IBD: So Guidewire's strength is not delivering software via the cloud. They're an exception to that preference. In this case it's their vertical integration that you like?

Dunn: Guidewire is primarily on-premise. Their software enables core business processes that need to be on premise. Yes, they're an exception. With Guidewire, we like how they have developed deep vertical expertise to disrupt an industry that has lacked software innovation for a long time.
IBD: Financials were one of your strongest sectors in the second quarter. What worked there?

Dunn: We don't own traditional financials like big banks. But we found what we think are interesting growth companies. One is WisdomTree (WETF), one of the largest ETF companies. They're benefiting from the flow of assets into passive investment vehicles.

We've got Charles Schwab (SCHW), which benefits from rising rates because of their money market funds. They've been losing money on their money market funds due to low rates. As rates rise, they can make money there. Rising rates are the biggest swing factor to earnings corporatewide.

Schwab brokerage clients have some portion of their assets in cash, in Schwab money market funds. Schwab normally charges a fee on assets. But with rates so low, Schwab has waived the fees. And of course on the banking side if rates go up, Schwab should benefit like any bank.
The stock has run up from 14 a share at the end of last year to around 21. So we trimmed around some big moves to get the weight at an appropriate level for us. We still like it.
IBD: Consumer staples was another successful Q2 sector. What do you like there?

Dunn: We've been underweight in consumer staples. We call them expensive defensives. But we do find some names in that space attractive. Monster Beverage (MNST) makes energy drinks. There's a secular trend toward energy drink consumption in the U.S. and around the world. And Monster is a leading player.
In consumer discretionary, we like Dollar Tree (DLTR). They're a value proposition, with a nice assortment of consumable and discount goods with good price points.
They have a base of about 4,800 stores, growing close to 10% a year with an opportunity to reach 7,000.
They also have a Canadian opportunity, with 160 stores that can go to 1,000.
They trade at a similar multiple to their peers, but we feel they're a better company. They have better real estate, merchandise mix, and long-term growth prospects.
IBD: Health care also helped. Why do you like Gilead Sciences (GILD)?

Dunn: They're a leader in the treatment of HIV. They've grown their share of HIV treatment from 40% in 2004 to 82% last year. And there are still a lot of infected patients who are not being treated, so there's room for patient growth.

Now they're moving into the hepatitis C market, which is huge. We think they have the best cure. They're trading at a single-digit P/E multiple. But at their rate of growth, they won't be growing at a single-digit pace. So there's an opportunity to get upside.
IBD: Energy is a small sector for you, but it was a third good one in Q2. What are some favorite plays?
Dunn: We own Continental Resources (CLR) and Sanchez Energy (SN). Both are shale plays.
IBD: CommVault Systems (CVLT) is new to the portfolio. What do you see powering the resumption of its uptrend after a wobbly Q2?
Dunn: We had been following it, waiting for an opportunity to get involved. We bought it in June when it had a pullback.
Their software provides backup, archive and recovery solutions. We think they're a best-of-breed market share gainer.

They've got multiple secular drivers: data growth, the move to the cloud, virtualization, mobility and the bring-your-own-device trend. They let companies reduce costs and risks associated with protecting, recovering and accessing data across an enterprise.

In their first-quarter conference call, they were cautious in their outlook, mirroring what a lot of tech companies were saying. We didn't see weakness in their results, but management's tone spooked people a little.
IBD: Priceline.com (PCLN) is up about 50% this year. You've indicated that you still find it attractive. How so?
Dunn: They're the best in the travel space. They were the first mover in Europe, and that market is still developing.
It does not have nearly the penetration of online travel booking as the U.S.
The hotel market is more fragmented, and Priceline is doing a better job than competitors at getting hotels onto their platform.
They have a first-mover, sustainable advantage there.
IBD: Stratasys (SSYS) is another newcomer to the portfolio. Why did you trim it shortly after opening your position?

Dunn: We bought it in March. Our trim was mostly to manage position size. It's an emerging-growth, early-stage stock that can be expensive and volatile. So we like to keep that sort of position at a reasonable range. But we think the 3D (prototyping) space is interesting, and they're an early pioneer.
IBD: LinkedIn (LNKD) has more than doubled this year. Did you trim in recent quarters for risk management or concerns over fundamentals?

Dunn: We bought in November when the stock was under pressure. We didn't have any concerns. We were just managing our size. The stock had grown into a bigger weight than we felt was appropriate. We've really liked them since they came public.

The thing that's attractive is that they've got the professional network locked down. We don't think there will be multiple professional networks. And we like the way they monetize their recruiter tools. Their talent solutions give employers access to this huge database of passive job seekers at a good price in comparison to using a recruiter.
IBD: CoStar Group (CSGP) is another relative newcomer. What do you like about this real estate data provider?
Dunn: They offer customers online access to a database of commercial real estate information, which has been researched and verified. That information is very valuable and difficult to replicate.

They are able to sell subscriptions to their clients, and they have very high renewal rates. The competitive barriers to entry are high. The business model is very profitable and scalable. And we may be in the early innings of a multiyear recovery in commercial real estate.
IBD: Portfolio Recovery (PRAA) is another name you've been trimming. Due to fundamentals or due to weight management?
Dunn: They've had a great performance, so the weight got bigger than what we think is appropriate. We continue to like them.

This stock can be controversial because it is debt collection business. They buy defaulted credit card portfolios at pennies on the dollar, then they try to collect. But they are the best operator in this business. Hedge funds and speculators used to bid on credit card receivables, then sell the portfolios to collection agencies. But many of those other buyershave left the market. So prices for defaulted portfolios are more attractive.
IBD: You've been trimming SVB Financial Group (SIVB). Another example of risk control, or are you concerned about fundamentals?
Dunn: This is the same story. It's been a strong stock, so we've been trimming to get back to an appropriate weight.

Silicon Valley Bank specializes in serving start-up and technology companies. They are also one of the few banks that benefits from higher interest rates. The majority of their loan book is floating rate and will benefit as rates move higher. And their net interest margin has been compressed by low interest rates.
Much of their deposits are in noninterest bearing checking accounts, so their cost of funding did not drop as rates declined, while their average loan rate did drop. We expect this to reverse.
IBD: Your 50-stock portfolio size is close to the 55-stock ceiling of your range. Have cash flows been above normal? And if they have, are you doing anything special to manage the inflow?
Dunn: Cash flow has been modestly positive. No portfolio management challenges. Positive cash flows allow us to proactively manage position sizes.
IBD: How do you and co-manager Tim Cunningham divvy up buy and sell decisions? Are you both generalists or do you each specialize in certain industries?

Dunn: Tim and I make all the buy and sell decisions together. Everyone on the team is working as a global generalist. We want to foster an environment of stock-picking, where analysts develop a broad set of analytical skills, and are evaluating investments in the context of the broader opportunity set, not just a narrow sector or industry.The managers of the $782 million Thornburg Core Growth Fund are jugglers.They blend and balance three types of growth stocks into their portfolio: mature industry leaders, consistent growers and emerging growers.That approach helped these managers extend their successful investing streak.
