It varies depending on whether we're finding a lot of opportunities and the risk profile of each investment. We're around 50 now.We consider our price target on each stock a representation of intrinsic value. And we don't own a stock unless we believe there is upside from the current price. So we always buy at a discount.Size flexibility reflects our three-basket structure. Our emerging-growth leaders tend to be more aggressive stocks, smaller and faster growing. They're generally sitting in front of a large opportunity.The second basket, our growth industry leaders, tends to be midcap or large caps. These have leadership positions. They're more mature companies.The third basket holds our consistent growers. They add a little defensive nature to the portfolio. They tend to have a good element of visibility. They often have a subscription model or recurring revenue and good earnings visibility.IBD: What sort of an edge do you get from your three-basket tack?Dunn: The three baskets add diversification. They let us balance risk from more conservative to more aggressive growth stocks. Stocks perform differently in different markets. This lets us aim for good performance throughout investment cycles.IBD: How do you divvy your cash among the three baskets?Dunn: We want about 33% in each.IBD: You make bottom-up investment decisions. But sector weights reflect where you tend to look for leaders. Why is software your largest sector currently?Dunn: There's a lot of innovation and change there. Part of our weighting is exposure to SaaS — software as a service. It is disruptive to software on the premises. Lower cost. Faster upgrade cycles.Another reason is that we like software companies that have expertise serving a specific vertical niche.Guidewire Software (GWRE), for example, developed a software platform for property and casualty insurers. The core platform covers policy claims and billing systems. For years the software that insurers used was in-house, antiquated, inflexible and expensive to maintain. Guidewire's works much better. Its value proposition is really strong. And it is addressing a big market, which is bigger than $10 billion. Their share is less than 5%. But they're starting to win big deals that validate them within the industry.IBD: So Guidewire's strength is not delivering software via the cloud. They're an exception to that preference. In this case it's their vertical integration that you like?Dunn: Guidewire is primarily on-premise. Their software enables core business processes that need to be on premise. Yes, they're an exception. With Guidewire, we like how they have developed deep vertical expertise to disrupt an industry that has lacked software innovation for a long time.IBD: Financials were one of your strongest sectors in the second quarter. What worked there?Dunn: We don't own traditional financials like big banks. But we found what we think are interesting growth companies. One is WisdomTree (WETF), one of the largest ETF companies. They're benefiting from the flow of assets into passive investment vehicles.We've got Charles Schwab (SCHW), which benefits from rising rates because of their money market funds. They've been losing money on their money market funds due to low rates. As rates rise, they can make money there. Rising rates are the biggest swing factor to earnings corporatewide.Schwab brokerage clients have some portion of their assets in cash, in Schwab money market funds. Schwab normally charges a fee on assets. But with rates so low, Schwab has waived the fees. And of course on the banking side if rates go up, Schwab should benefit like any bank.The stock has run up from 14 a share at the end of last year to around 21. So we trimmed around some big moves to get the weight at an appropriate level for us. We still like it.IBD: Consumer staples was another successful Q2 sector. What do you like there?Dunn: We've been underweight in consumer staples. We call them expensive defensives. But we do find some names in that space attractive. Monster Beverage (MNST) makes energy drinks. There's a secular trend toward energy drink consumption in the U.S. and around the world. And Monster is a leading player.In consumer discretionary, we like Dollar Tree (DLTR). They're a value proposition, with a nice assortment of consumable and discount goods with good price points.They have a base of about 4,800 stores, growing close to 10% a year with an opportunity to reach 7,000.They also have a Canadian opportunity, with 160 stores that can go to 1,000.They trade at a similar multiple to their peers, but we feel they're a better company. They have better real estate, merchandise mix, and long-term growth prospects.IBD: Health care also helped. Why do you like Gilead Sciences (GILD)?Dunn: They're a leader in the treatment of HIV. They've grown their share of HIV treatment from 40% in 2004 to 82% last year. And there are still a lot of infected patients who are not being treated, so there's room for patient growth.Now they're moving into the hepatitis C market, which is huge. We think they have the best cure. They're trading at a single-digit P/E multiple. But at their rate of growth, they won't be growing at a single-digit pace. So there's an opportunity to get upside.IBD: Energy is a small sector for you, but it was a third good one in Q2. What are some favorite plays?Dunn: We own Continental Resources (CLR) and Sanchez Energy (SN). Both are shale plays.IBD: CommVault Systems (CVLT) is new to the portfolio. What do you see powering the resumption of its uptrend after a wobbly Q2?Dunn: We had been following it, waiting for an opportunity to get involved. We bought it in June when it had a pullback.Their software provides backup, archive and recovery solutions. We think they're a best-of-breed market share gainer.They've got multiple secular drivers: data growth, the move to the cloud, virtualization, mobility and the bring-your-own-device trend. They let companies reduce costs and risks associated with protecting, recovering and accessing data across an enterprise.In their first-quarter conference call, they were cautious in their outlook, mirroring what a lot of tech companies were saying. We didn't see weakness in their results, but management's tone spooked people a little.IBD: Priceline.com (PCLN) is up about 50% this year. You've indicated that you still find it attractive. How so?Dunn: They're the best in the travel space. They were the first mover in Europe, and that market is still developing.It does not have nearly the penetration of online travel booking as the U.S.The hotel market is more fragmented, and Priceline is doing a better job than competitors at getting hotels onto their platform.They have a first-mover, sustainable advantage there.IBD: Stratasys (SSYS) is another newcomer to the portfolio. Why did you trim it shortly after opening your position?Dunn: We bought it in March. Our trim was mostly to manage position size. It's an emerging-growth, early-stage stock that can be expensive and volatile. So we like to keep that sort of position at a reasonable range. But we think the 3D (prototyping) space is interesting, and they're an early pioneer.IBD: LinkedIn (LNKD) has more than doubled this year. Did you trim in recent quarters for risk management or concerns over fundamentals?Dunn: We bought in November when the stock was under pressure. We didn't have any concerns. We were just managing our size. The stock had grown into a bigger weight than we felt was appropriate. We've really liked them since they came public.The thing that's attractive is that they've got the professional network locked down. We don't think there will be multiple professional networks. And we like the way they monetize their recruiter tools. Their talent solutions give employers access to this huge database of passive job seekers at a good price in comparison to using a recruiter.IBD: CoStar Group (CSGP) is another relative newcomer. What do you like about this real estate data provider?Dunn: They offer customers online access to a database of commercial real estate information, which has been researched and verified. That information is very valuable and difficult to replicate.They are able to sell subscriptions to their clients, and they have very high renewal rates. The competitive barriers to entry are high. The business model is very profitable and scalable. And we may be in the early innings of a multiyear recovery in commercial real estate.IBD: Portfolio Recovery (PRAA) is another name you've been trimming. Due to fundamentals or due to weight management?Dunn: They've had a great performance, so the weight got bigger than what we think is appropriate. We continue to like them.This stock can be controversial because it is debt collection business. They buy defaulted credit card portfolios at pennies on the dollar, then they try to collect. But they are the best operator in this business. Hedge funds and speculators used to bid on credit card receivables, then sell the portfolios to collection agencies. But many of those other buyershave left the market. So prices for defaulted portfolios are more attractive.IBD: You've been trimming SVB Financial Group (SIVB). Another example of risk control, or are you concerned about fundamentals?Dunn: This is the same story. It's been a strong stock, so we've been trimming to get back to an appropriate weight.Silicon Valley Bank specializes in serving start-up and technology companies. They are also one of the few banks that benefits from higher interest rates. The majority of their loan book is floating rate and will benefit as rates move higher. And their net interest margin has been compressed by low interest rates.Much of their deposits are in noninterest bearing checking accounts, so their cost of funding did not drop as rates declined, while their average loan rate did drop. We expect this to reverse.IBD: Your 50-stock portfolio size is close to the 55-stock ceiling of your range. Have cash flows been above normal? And if they have, are you doing anything special to manage the inflow?Dunn: Cash flow has been modestly positive. No portfolio management challenges. Positive cash flows allow us to proactively manage position sizes.IBD: How do you and co-manager Tim Cunningham divvy up buy and sell decisions? Are you both generalists or do you each specialize in certain industries?Dunn: Tim and I make all the buy and sell decisions together. Everyone on the team is working as a global generalist. We want to foster an environment of stock-picking, where analysts develop a broad set of analytical skills, and are evaluating investments in the context of the broader opportunity set, not just a narrow sector or industry.
Monster Beverage (MNST) surged 4.7% intraday to 101.55, an all-time high, after it was upgraded by Goldman Sachs (GS) to buy.
Its shares cooled slightly later in the day and were up 2.9% at 99.79 at 1:30 p.m. ET.
Goldman expects Monster's new Rehab drink to fuel the energy-drink producer's growth.
Monster is marketing the Rehab as "One that can do it all — a triple threat that quenches thirst, hydrates like a sports drink, and brings you back after a hard day's night."
Earlier this month, Monster announced plans for a 2-for-1 stock split on Feb. 15, increasing its shares to 174.3 million.

The company, formerly Hansen Natural, changed its name and ticker symbol in January to emphasize its biggest brand. Hansen's third-quarter sales increased 24% to $474.7 million and its EPS increased 22% to 88 cents.
The energy-drink market grew 16% in the first six months of 2011, according to Beverage Digest, but Monster isn't alone in the market. Austria-based Red Bull is the company's biggest rival.

In August, Red Bull led the energy-drink market in dollars, with a 33% share vs. Monster's 28% share. But Monster beats Red Bull in total sales volume, 36% of the market to Red Bull's 25%, according to John Sicher, editor and publisher of Beverage Digest.

Monster also faces competition from Pepsi's (PEP) Amp energy drink and the Rockstar energy drink produced by privately held Rockstar.Monster Beverage (MNST) surged 4.7% intraday to 101.55, an all-time high, after it was upgraded by Goldman Sachs (GS) to buy.Its shares cooled slightly later in the day and were up 2.9% at 99.79 at 1:30 p.m. ET.Goldman expects Monster's new Rehab drink to fuel the energy-drink producer's growth.Monster is marketing the Rehab as "One that can do it all — a triple threat that quenches thirst, hydrates like a sports drink, and brings you back after a hard day's night."Earlier this month, Monster announced plans for a 2-for-1 stock split on Feb. 15, increasing its shares to 174.3 million.The company, formerly Hansen Natural, changed its name and ticker symbol in January to emphasize its biggest brand. Trade tracked about 25% lower on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq. The morning's biggest market news may have been General Electric's (GE) $3.3 billion acquisition of Lufkin Industries (LUFK),…

Coke and its partner Select Milk Producers bought equity stakes in the newly formed Fair Oaks Farms Brands, the maker of the Core Power protein beverage. Financial terms were not disclosed. Stocks are like people. They put in their best performances while still enjoying the fresh blush of youth. (Some, of course, are late bloomers.)Research shows that stocks often put in their best gains within the first 15 years of going public. (Not long ago, IBD's guideline was restricted to eight years or less.)A raft of reasons explains this youthful exuberance.The biggest factor is the N — for New — in CAN SLIM. Big, stodgy companies can come up with new products, new ideas or new technologies. But the added revenue may hardly move the needle.Often it's the young guns that come in with a new way of doing things. In fact, that's often why the young company was formed in the first place. Maybe the new idea is an energy drink, a niche no one knew existed before Hansen Natural (now known as Monster Beverage (MNST) came out with its eponymous energy drink. The funny-looking cans hit the shelves, and a star is born. What's more, being a new concept, where's the competition? There isn't any for some time.Then, too, consider the different corporate structures of big vs. small. The young guns take out some office space and get to work on their brainchild. The new idea may well already exist, but the small firm's efforts are focused on complete execution.Now take a new idea and put it in the mid-management level of  IBM (IBM). A flash of brilliance can easily get lost in that mammoth company. Navigating the ocean of bureaucracy seems a very daunting task. Some entrenched powers may fear change. They're experts at doing things a certain way.But OK, let's say IBM recognizes the new idea. After all, this is a company that has survived for decades in an industry that thrives on new developments. We know that new ideas do get to the execution stage.Now you must deal with the economic impact of this new idea on the company.So IBM develops a new technology that puts a new twist on Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) technology to help keep computer networks safe and efficient.That new unit would be very profitable. But against the backdrop of IBM's mammoth billings, the stock would likely benefit only mildly.Take that same new technology — and the genius who created it — and start a new company. Let's just call it Mellanox Technologies (MLNX). We'll base it in Israel and market to companies all over the world. That very same idea, rather than being lost in the shuffle, becomes the force behind one of the market's hottest stocks. The stock has powered 85% since moving past an early 61.50 buy point in June. 1

Most sector-leading stocks fell in weak trade Tuesday, led by Polaris Industries (PII) and newcomer Monster Beverage (MNST). Software leader Sourcefire (FIRE) was a rare bright spot, retaking its 50-day line after jumping 1.54, or 3%, in strong volume. However, the stock was down sharply after hours following the company's announcement that Q2 profit doubled from a year ago to…
Stock futures winked in and out of mixed trade ahead of Thursday's open, as weak economic data counter-balanced a rebound among many commodities-related stocks.
Dow futures shed 8.3 points. Nasdaq 100 futures showed a 4.5-point gain. S&P 500 futures traded less than 1% below fair market value.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 have both slipped in five of the past six sessions. The Nasdaq remains above its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages, a positive. The S&P 500 on Wednesday stabbed straight through both lines of support in above-average trade — not good. Distribution days continue to climb, signaling selling by large investors and placing yet more pressure on the market.
So far for the week, the Nasdaq starts the session down 2.3%. The S&P 500 opens 2.1% in the hole. Small caps are clearly lagging, with the Russell 2000 and the S&P Small Cap 600 each off 3.2%.
The stock market today gets the week's first real dose of economic news.

The Labor Department reported unemployment claims veered sharply higher, to 282,000 claims, in the week ended Dec. 5. That was nearly 5% above the prior week's tally and far above economists' consensus projections for 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 270,750, its second straight gain.

Prices of exports slipped more than expected in November, down 0.6% vs. forecasts for a 0.3% slip. That means U.S. producers are being paid less for their goods. Import prices also slipped less than expected, down 0.4% vs. estimates for a 0.8% decline.
The Treasury is due to report its November budget at 2 p.m.
In stocks, the Dow was flat to positive with advancing stocks holding to gains of less than 0.5%. DuPont (DD) trailed the group with a 1.1% slip.
Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) topped the S&P 500, up about 3% each.

At the bottom of the index, First Solar (FSLR) dropped 9% after the company released 2016 guidance late Wednesday. The midpoint of revenue projections of between $3.9 billion and $4.1 billion missed analyst expectations.
Gold miners mustered a premarket rally, with Anglogold Ashanti (AU) and Sibanye Gold (SBGL) ahead around 6% before the bell.

Fiber optic gear maker Ciena (CIEN) crumbled 10%. The Hanover, Md.-based operation reported better-than-expected fiscal fourth quarter sales and earnings, but management's Q1 and full-year revenue guidance stopped short of analyst projections.

Men'S Wearhouse (MW) tanked 20% after reporting weak Q3 revenue late Wednesday. Comparable sales at Jos. A. Bank stores fell 14.1%. in the quarter, and management said Q4-to-date comparable sales were down 35.1% at Jos. A. Bank stores, but up 5.5% across the rest of the company.
Most leaders on the IBD 50 list were flat ahead of the open. Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) and ARM Holdings (ARMH) topped the group, up slightly more than 1% each.
On Wednesday, Dave & Buster's aggressively trimmed a 9% early gain to a 0.3% advance at the close. The backtrack pulled shares back below a 40.90 buy point in a double-bottom base.
At the other end of the IBD 50 list, Tesoro (TSO) dropped 0.7% — the worst premarket loss in the group.

Markets overseas moved generally lower. The main indexes in Hong Kong and Shanghai fell 0.5% each. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo gave up 1.3%, putting it down 2.3% so far for the week. In Europe, leading indexes in Paris, London and Frankfurt were down less than 0.5% at midday. IBD readers know that the right time to buy stocks is when the market is in a clear uptrend. So is the inverse true? Should you sell shares short only when the market is in a clear correction? Yes. And sometimes no. When a correction becomes a bear market — a 20% or greater decline or from the recent high…
Stocks were again off their session lows, but still slightly lower Friday afternoon.

The Nasdaq fell 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 slipped 0.2% each. All three have been trading in choppy fashion since hitting a three-month high Tuesday. Volume was tracking lower across the board.

Monster Beverage (MNST) was slightly off its worst levels, but still down 8% after gapping below its 200-day line. The beverage distributor tumbled to a five-month low on news that an unspecified state attorney general is probing the ingredients and marketing of its flagship Monster Energy drink. The stock had already been hammered Thursday in reaction to worse-than-expected Q2 results.

GNC Holdings (GNC) gave up earlier gains, fell 3% and sliced its 50-day moving average. Late Thursday, the nutritional supplements maker announced a secondary offering of 10 million shares to be sold by certain shareholders. GNC will buy back 6 million shares after the offering. The stock has been trading in choppy fashion after a failed breakout last month.

Elli Mae (ELLI) turned lower and lost 4%. The downside reversal erased the bulk of Thursday's move. The stock is still well extended after rebounding off its 50-day line. Elli Mae provides electronic mortgage origination services. Analysts see its earnings surging 204% to 73 cents a share this year. It currently hosts an 82 EPS Rating.

Scripps Networks Interactive (SNI) reversed earlier losses and rose 1% to an all-time high. It's now almost 4% past a 57.85 buy point in a flat base. Earlier this month, the owner of the Food Network TV channel beat Wall Street estimates with a 19% rise in Q2 earnings, thanks to strong ad sales. Stocks slipped in morning trade as the indexes set up for a possible third straight loss Tuesday. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 lost 0.5% each. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%. Volume fell on both major exchanges. The indexes, though, were holding above their 50-day moving averages. About a dozen stocks in the IBD 50, a proxy for…
Energy drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST) was savaged after hours on results that missed Wall Street expectations. Shares closed down 1.6% at 67.77, and tumbled 10% following the market close.

The beverage firm reported earnings of 59 cents per share, up from 45 cents a year ago. Revenue climbed 28.2% to $592.6 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 61 cents on revenue of $596.1 million. Gross margin slipped to 51.8%, from 52.8 a year ago.
The company said the energy drink sector in the U.S. and Europe was still growing, and that Monster was growing faster than that category.

Earlier Wednesday the home carbonated beverage machine maker SodaStream (SODA) posted stronger-than-expected results, in part on strong U.S. and Western Europe sales. The Israeli company upped its guidance, and popped higher earlier in the day, but closed down 7% at 40.97.
Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) climbed 5.7% Wednesday and coffeehouse chain Caribou Coffee (CBOU) was up 5.3%.

Stock futures eased lower ahead of Friday's open, as the dollar gained and Q4 GDP data came in below expectations.Dow futures slipped 17.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were off 2.3 points. Nasdaq futures shifted from gains to a 1.5-point loss an hour before the start of regular trade.Stock Market TodayThe stock market today starts with the Nasdaq steering toward its worst week since October, down 3.2% through Thursday. The S&P 500 opens with a 2.5% loss for the week. Both indexes are testing support at their 50-day moving averages while toting a hefty count of seven distribution days each.The Nasdaq may be gathering itself to again challenge resistance at the 5000 level. But maintaining support at the 50-day line will be the crucial test on Friday.Economic NewsThe Commerce Department reported its estimate for Q4 GDP growth was 2.2%, unchanged from prior estimates, but below economist projections for an upward revision to 2.4%. The GDP price deflator inflation gauge held steady, up 0.1%, in line with expectations.A final reading on March consumer sentiment is expected from the University of Michigan at 10 a.m. ET. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen is scheduled to speak in San Francisco, beginning at 3:45 p.m. ET.StocksOlin (OLN) rocketed 20% higher on news that Dow Chemical (DOW) would merge its chlorine operations with Olin. The companies expect the deal, valued at $5 billion, to form an industry leader in chloralkali processing, producing vinyl, chlorinated organics and epoxy.Dow shares rose 6% in premarket trade. Olin had pulled back below a 15-month high after briefly clearing a long-term consolidation. Dow has been consolidating since September.Restoration Hardware (RH) slumped more than 4% ahead of the opening bell. The Corte Madera, Calif.-based chain reported late Thursday a narrow Q4 earnings beat and sales in line with expectations. Q1 guidance was below analyst targets. The stock has been forming a base-on-base cup, ending Thursday back above its 10-week line of support.Yahoo (YHOO) added nearly 2% after its late Thursday announcement of a $2 billion share buyback initiative. The company reported the new program was in addition to the $726 million in buybacks still active under its previous plan.Morgan Stanley launched coverage on the stock with an overweight rating and a 55 price target. Yahoo shares have been working to retake their 10-week moving average, within a four-month consolidation.OverseasChina's markets ended relatively flat on Friday after a week that left the Shanghai Composite up 2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index with a 2.7% gain. Stocks opened to modest losses Thursday, as company reports, jobs data and oil prices figured into early trade. The Dow dropped 0.9%. The Nasdaq narrowed its early loss to 0.4%. The S&P 500 hung 0.6% into the red.
Volume climbed 10% on the Nasdaq and was 29% higher on the NYSE, relative to trade at the same time Wednesday.

The stock market today got started on weak footing after the Labor Department reported jobless claims held steady in the week ending Nov. 7. This followed an unexpected surge in the prior week. Investors were also taking in early comments made in separate speeches by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, St. Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard and Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Richmond Federal Reserve Bank.

U.S. employers claimed 5.53 million positions went unfilled in the Labor Department's September Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey. The number was up from 5.37 million unfilled openings in August.
Oil prices were down sharply, with West Texas Intermediate off more than 2% to below $42 a barrel ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories report, due out at 11 a.m. ET.

In stocks,Goldman Sachs (GS) and Boeing (BA) weighed on the Dow, down 2% each. Cisco Systems (CSCO) held the Dow's high ground, up a half percent before its fiscal first quarter report due out after the close. Sellers were piling on mining issues, with Freeport-McMoran (FCX) down 7% and Consol Energy (CNX) down 5% in early action.

Advance Auto Parts (AAP) peeled off a 12% loss. The Roanoke, Va.-based chain's third-quarter earnings and revenue missed estimates, guidance was weak and the Chief Executive Darren Jackson announced he would retire Jan. 2. The gap-down loss drove shares well below their 50-day moving average in very heavy trade.

On the IBD 50 list, NetEase (NTES) climbed almost 4% in strong trade, to just above two optional cup base buy points, one at 154.62 and another at 154.98. The China-based provider of online games and content reported strong third quarterly results late Wednesday.

On the downside, operations management consultant Maximus (MMS) buckled, falling 25%. The Reston, Va.-based operation reported fiscal fourth quarter earnings a penny above consensus views, but revenue stopped shy of forecasts and management trimmed its full year EPS guidance. The loss ends the stock's effort to rise above a 70.10 cup-base buy point.Stocks opened to modest losses Thursday, as company reports, jobs data and oil prices figured into early trade. Update: Coca-Cola (KO) said shortly before Monday's market close that "we are not in discussions to acquire the Monster Beverage Corporation," denying a an earlier Wall Street Journal report that it's was in talks to buy out the energy drink maker. Monster Beverage (MNST) shares, up as much as 28% intraday, erased all its gains and closed down 0.8% to 65.
Coca-Cola (KO) is in talks to move from being a distributor to owning Monster Beverage (MNST), the fast-growing energy drink maker, reports said.
Monster, with a market capitalization topping $11 billion, would be the biggest brand acquisition for Coke, the world's largest soft-drink maker, the Wall Street Journal reported.
Monster shares soared as much as 28% intraday on the report. They were up nearly 17% to 76.50 in afternoon trading.
For first-quarter 2012 ending in March, analysts forecast Monster's EPS climbed 30% to 38 cents, on a 25% hike in revenue, to $447.1 million.
Coke shares fell 0.6% to 76.16, and archrival PepsiCo (PEP) slipped 24 cents to 65.86.
Coca-Cola and Monster both initially declined to comment, and the report didn't indicate sale price or other terms.

Monster has grown in part via its global distribution agreement with Coke. But the relationship has at times been an uneasy one, with Coke taking aim at Monster earlier with its own energy drinks, like Full Throttle.
Private Rockstar, distributed by PepsiCo, could also come into play if the Monster acquisition succeeds.
The market leader is Austria-based Red Bull, whose sales have grown rapidly in part on its distinctive "Red Bull gives you wings" TV marketing campaign.

Monster started as a natural soft drinks maker, known as Hansen Natural. The report follows earlier rumors of a possible deal between the two beverage giants that surfaced after they inked the distribution pact.
For its most recent three quarters, Monster posted earnings per share growth of 29%, 22% and 35%. Sales accelerated 26%, 24% and 29% during that period.
Investors will be watching the company's earnings closely when it reports first-quarter results.

The previous quarter, it missed analysts estimates after topping in the first three periods last year. Sell Winners Like A Pro: Seventh In A Series
Companies with high share prices often conduct stock splits to lure more investors. But too many splits can signal that the share price has peaked and it's time to sell.
Stock splits work as follows: In a 2-to-1 split, an investor who owns one share of a stock at $100 gets two shares worth $50 each.

Investors who previously couldn't afford a share of stock may now be able to buy, potentially allowing the company to raise more money. Companies sometimes split their stocks in a 3-to-1 ratio, a 4-to-1 ratio or even a 10-to-1 ratio.

While a single stock split might be effective early in a new bull market, two or three splits could flood the market and weigh on the share price. That's especially true if the splits come within just a year or two of each other.
"A stock will often reach a price top around the second or third time it splits," wrote IBD founder and Chairman William O'Neil in "How to Make Money in Stocks."
Furthermore, IBD research has shown that only 18% of the biggest winners had splits in the year before their big run-ups.

Quality Systems (QSII), a provider of health care information technology products, broke out above an 18.15 buy point from a flat base on top of a longer base on Oct. 21, 2002 (before splits). By early 2005, the stock had doubled. The company announced a 2-to-1 stock split taking effect April 1 1 (monthly chart is shown).

Quality Systems continued to rise sharply after the move, hitting a split-adjusted high of 45.97 in the week ended Feb. 10, 2006. That peak roughly coincided with a declaration of a second 2-to-1 split on Jan. 31, 2006, just one year after the first split 2.
But by around the time the second split took effect on March 31, the stock had plummeted 38% to a trough of 28.30 3. It traded sideways for the next 2-1/2 years as the S&P 500 trended higher.

Other stocks that had their big runs halted following a rush of stock splits included Hansen's Natural (MNST) (now Monster Beverage) in 2005 and 2006, Titanium Metals (TIE) in 2004 to 2006 and Dell (DELL) in the late 1990s.

A pair of 2-to-1 stock splits launched by Quality Systems resulted in a quadrupling in shares outstanding. The dramatic rise in share supply can put a lot of downward pressure on a stock, especially in a market correction.
"Knowledgeable pros and a few shrewd individual traders will probably use the excitement generated by the oversized split as an opportunity to sell and take their profits," O'Neil wrote.

Obviously, you want to buy a stock that's in strong demand. In that case, it may be best to look for companies that buy back their shares, reducing supply, rather than chasing stock splits.Sell Winners Like A Pro: Seventh In A SeriesCompanies with high share prices often conduct stock splits to lure more investors. As other investors again began taking aim at rallying growth stocks in Q1, Nuveen Mid Cap Growth Opportunities was already locked and loaded.The $1.2 billion fund galloped ahead 17.26% in Q1 vs. 14.60% on average for midcap growth funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. and 12.59% for the S&P 500.Faring better than many funds in the recent broad market pullback, it is up 15.82% so far this year going into Tuesday vs. 11.17% for its peers and 9.38% for the big-cap bogey.In contrast, in Q4 the fund's 7.15% gain lagged its peers' 10.36% and the S&P500's 11.82%. The fund's favorites were consumer discretionary names like Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and tech names such as computer storage service provider  Teradata (TDC).Exposure to emerging markets like China also hurt the fund.Now the fund is being rewarded for keeping its focus on stocks like those, which it calls exceptional growth companies."We have an approach to developing a growth thesis," said lead manager James Diedrich. "We don't change that based on what the market is doing."Lululemon's earnings per share grew 50% and 59% the past two quarters."They have a long runway of growth," Diedrich said. He cited expansion outside the U.S. and Canada, into men's wear and into additional types of apparel."They have good financial metrics, which is part of what we use in developing a thesis," he added.Maybe, but Lululemon, up 58% this year, plunged below its 10-week line. That left it 4% above its 67.32 buy point set Feb. 15.Data WranglerThe fund has held Teradata since its 2007 IPO. The firm provides enterprise data warehousing. One driver is regulatory rules that require companies to keep ever more data. Another is the volcanic growth of data.EPS grew 25% to 30% the past three quarters. Pretax margin has grown three straight years.VeriFone Systems (PAY), up 47% so far this year, bounced off its 10-week moving average Monday and continued higher Tuesday, but in tepid volume.Takeover SpreeThe provider of point-of-sale services is continuing a buying spree by taking over rival Hypercom.Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA) are adopting stricter security, which require merchants to upgrade their point-of-sale terminals from VeriFone.The number of VeriFone terminals in use should increase about 50%.The company is also expanding its use of video terminals at gasoline pumps that carry advertising.And VeriFone benefits from the explosion in wireless payments via smartphones.Morningstar classifies Monster Beverage (MNST) as a consumer cyclical. But it acts like a growthy discretionary name."They are a play on energy drinks gaining market share in the U.S.," Diedrich said.Monster, in the portfolio a few quarters, is 29% past its split-adjusted 48.75 buy point in a flat base.The beverage maker's earnings per share growth ranged from 22% to 67% in the past four quarters. Analysts see Q1 EPS up 27%.

Monster Beverage  (MNST) has an uncommon approach to advertising on TV, radio, and billboards. It avoids it.

Unlike beverage giants Coca-Cola (KO) and Pepsi (PEP), which drown the airwaves with commercials, Monster Beverage, which is based in Corona, Calif., nixes mainstream marketing. It doesn't even have an ad agency.

You might ask how Monster and its No. 1 seller, Monster Energy, generated $1.3 billion in 2011 revenue. Or how it slipped past privately owned Red Bull to become No. 1 in energy-drink convenience-store sales. Another question is why Coke and Pepsi haven't caught up.
The answer is that for some products, traditional advertising doesn't work. Tapping unique ways to market a brand while eschewing mainstream advertising can be an effective way to grow.

Part of Monster Energy's success stems from "knowing its audience and finding a way to connect with them, in what they perceive as an authentic way, and not talking down to them," said Jeff Cioletti, editor of industry trade publication Beverage World.

The dominant audience for Monster Energy is made up of teens and people in their early 20s who want a pick-me-up drink for a quick boost. They're suspicious of traditional advertising, and Monster Energy ads on TV and radio would likely alienate them, analysts say.

In lieu of taking out ads, Monster Energy promotes events and competitions in extreme sports — skateboarding, motorcycle racing, surfing — and sponsors Nascar driver Robby Gordon. Similarly, rival Red Bull sponsors its own professional soccer team and targets more mainstream sporting fans.

Monster recognized early that its core consumer was 18 to 30 years old and seeking a drink that would boost their energy levels, so it targeted that demographic, said Scott Van Winkle, a Boston-based industry analyst at Canaccord Genuity. To boost its brand at the outset, it used guerrilla marketing to hand out free cans of Monster at events to create buzz.

Why waste time taking out costly Super Bowl ads with 110 million impressions and reach only a fraction of its audience? Van Winkle asked. He notes that skateboarding and surfing promotions target Monster's audience exclusively.
On Facebook, Twitter
To appeal to its mostly 20-something audience, Monster Beverage has nurtured a strong following on social networks. It counts 14 million enthusiasts on Facebook and has 154,000 Twitter followers.

Rejecting traditional advertising hasn't slowed Monster Energy's popularity. Monster had 31.5% market share in convenience-store sales in 2010, followed by Red Bull's 30.7%, Rockstar's 14% and Amp's 6%, according to Beverage Marketing. Cioletti says Monster passed Red Bull based on its effective branding campaign and making the right distribution deals to expand its network.

In the last several years, the energy-drink audience has increased about 7% annually, Cioletti said. He expects it to keep growing. But he's concerned about campaigns started by nutrition groups about the excessive amount of caffeine in the 16-ounce and larger Monster Energy cans. If the resistance gains traction and stirs a backlash, it could damage growth. But Van Winkle says the chance of government regulation of sales is slim.
In fact, Van Winkle noted that only 16% of adults over the age of 18 consume energy drinks, so there's room for growth in that demographic. It also has older fans.
Going To Rehab

Van Winkle credits Monster Beverage's increasing market share to its innovative new Rehab line that includes the superconcentrated M3 beverage and 17-ounce energy brew Ubermonster. The Rehab line appeals to young people who drink in the morning to recover from a night out partying (hence the name Rehab). It also introduced Java Monster, a coffee-flavored energy drink, and Hansen's sparkling-water line.
In addition, Van Winkle says Monster grows share by sticking with its core brand, avoiding acquisitions and not taking big gambles in new product categories.
Monster Beverage has a diverse portfolio. It includes its original lines of Hansen's natural soda and Peace Tea iced teas, though Van Winkle says Monster Energy contributes over 90% of its revenue.
Van Winkle expects about 19% sales growth for Monster in 2012. It's growing in Europe and making an Asian push, and its U.S. energy-drink sales are seen spiking 10%.

Coke and Pepsi have been playing catch-up against its feisty but smaller rivals, Monster Energy and Red Bull. Pepsi acquired energy brands SoBe Adrenaline Rush and SoBe No Fear and launched Mountain Dew Amp, but hasn't amassed much beyond 15% of the market. Neither has Coke scored with the energy drink Full Throttle.

In fact, Van Winkle quips that the minute Coca-Cola put its name on Full Throttle it undermined its success. "Anti-establishment" audiences don't crave a Coke energy drink, he says.Monster Beverage  (MNST) has an uncommon approach to advertising on TV, radio, and billboards. Stocks continued to trade in mixed territory at midday Friday, as investors digested a mixed batch of earnings reports.

The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.3%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 pulled back 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. Volume was tracking up from Thursday's levels across the board — sharply higher for the NYSE, but just slightly higher for the Nasdaq.

Intel (INTC) jumped as much as 2% in huge turnover, touching a new multiyear high. Late Thursday, the chip giant reported fourth-quarter EPS and sales that beat views, while also providing in-line guidance for the current period. Intel has been rallying off support at its 10-week moving average after clearing a 23.49 double-bottom buy point in October. The stock sports an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a best-possible 99.

Monster Beverage (MNST), formerly known as Hansen Natural, jumped 3% in big trade and reached a fresh peak. The energy drinks maker is on pace for a 7% gain for the week, with much of the advance coming after an upgrade to a buy rating from Goldman Sachs on Tuesday. Monster is now more than 5% beyond a 98.46 buy point that it cleared Tuesday. It has a 97 Composite Rating and ranks No. 17 in this week's IBD 50.

On the downside, MasterCard (MA) lost 4% in strong volume, dropping below the 350 level and further under its 50-day moving average. MasterCard, No. 17 in the IBD 50, could be getting hit by some weak quarterly reports by other credit card providers.

On Thursday, rival Capital One Financial (COF) reported quarterly profit that missed expectations, while American Express' (AXP) profit beat views, but revenue missed and it set aside more money for bad loans.
Separately, MasterCard recently claimed the No. 1 spot on this year's Bloomberg Businessweek 50 list of top-performing companies.

In U.S. economic news Friday, existing-home sales rose 5% month over month to an annual rate of 4.61 million.Stocks continued to trade in mixed territory at midday Friday, as investors digested a mixed batch of earnings reports.The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.3%, while the Nasdaq and S&P 500 pulled back 0.3% and 0.4%, respectively. Volume was tracking up from Thursday's levels across the board — sharply higher for the NYSE, but just slightly higher for the Nasdaq.Intel (INTC) jumped as much as 2% in huge turnover, touching a new multiyear high. Late Thursday, the chip giant reported fourth-quarter EPS and sales that beat views, while also providing in-line guidance for the current period. Intel has been rallying off support at its 10-week moving average after clearing a 23.49 double-bottom buy point in October. The stock sports an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a best-possible 99.Monster Beverage (MNST), formerly known as Hansen Natural, jumped 3% in big trade and reached a fresh peak. Most top stocks fell in low volume Monday despite gains in the major averages. But real estate leader RealPage (RP) jumped 2% in strong volume and Israeli chip designer Mellanox (MLNX) hit a new high. RealPage, which develops software to help landlords manage their properties, climbed 0.50 to 24.51 in almost double its average daily volume. The stock staged an…
Stocks continued to trade in narrowly mixed territory late Thursday.
The Nasdaq rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 eked out a 0.1% gain. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average was fractionally lower. Volume was again tracking lower across the board.

FleetCor Technologies (FLT) was off its session high, but still up 9% after topping views and raising guidance late Wednesday. The company earned 73 cents a share in the second quarter, up 28% from a year ago. It beat views by 8 cents. Sales climbed 28% to $171.8 million. Fleetcor now sees full-year profit coming in at $2.74 to $2.78 a share vs. views for $2.58 a share. The stock is in a cup base with a 41.40 buy point.

Express Scripts (ESRX) rose 3% to a new high in heavy trading. It's now 11% past a 56.30 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared July 13. However, that move lacked big volume. An investor could regard 59.08 — the left-side high plus 10 cents — as a more valid entry. The stock cleared that buy point in strong volume Wednesday and is 6% past the entry.

Late Tuesday, the pharmacy benefits manager beat analysts' expectations with a 24% rise in its Q2 earnings and a 144% pop in sales. The revenue surge was largely due to its buyout of Medco Health Solutions, completed in April. Management raised full-year EPS guidance to above consensus views.

Valspar (VAL) pushed its gain to 4% in heavy trading and climbed further north of its 50-day moving average barely regained Wednesday. The stock had fallen more than 8% from a 53.06 buy month earlier this month, but has been rebounding since. Valspar will report fiscal Q3 results Aug. 14. Analysts see the paint company's earnings rising 20% to 84 cents a share. Sales are slated to rise about 6% to $1.13 billion.

On the downside, Monster Beverage (MNST) was near its session low and down 8% after reporting disappointing Q2 results late Wednesday. The energy drink maker's second-quarter earnings came in at 59 cents a share, or 2 cents below views. Sales of $592.6 million missed expectations of $596.1 million. The company cited higher-than-expected costs in its international expansion efforts. Its gross margin slipped to 51.8% from 52.8% a year ago. The stock is now 26% off its April 30 peak.

SodaStream International (SODA) trimmed its loss to 1%, but looked to be on pace for its third straight loss. The stock had turned tail in the past two sessions. On Wednesday, the maker of home carbonation systems beat views with a 37% jump in Q2 earnings and a 49% gain in sales. SodaStream also raised its full-year growth forecast for profit and revenue. The major stock averages gapped lower Monday morning, after news from Europe and China had already sparked sell-offs abroad. But volume in the U.S. never roared, and stocks pared some of their losses by day's end.

The Nasdaq, which had plunged as much as 2.5% in the first hour, ended off just 1.2%. The S&P 500 cut its loss to 0.9% from 1.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average cut its loss from 1.9% to 0.8%.
Volume fell on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.

The news from Europe was bleak. Even as the ink dries on a plan to help out that country's banks, investors must now cope with aid requests from provincial governments. And ever-more serious talk is circulating that Greece may exit the eurozone. Representatives from the European Central Bank and the International Monetary Fund, the sources of Greece's bailout funds and emergence credit, will arrive in Athens for talks Tuesday.

Doubts are growing that Greece will meet its objectives in dealing with its crisis, and the other EU members will be reluctant to issue more bailout funds if it can't. "If Greece doesn't fulfill those conditions, then there can be no more payments," said German Vice Chancellor Philipp Roesler.
The euro dropped to a new two-year low. But, like the stock market, it pared much of that loss by day's end.

Also harmful was a warning by an adviser to the Bank of China that the emerging giant's economy will register smaller-than-expected growth in the current quarter. That would make for the seventh straight deceleration in GDP.

Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) gapped below its 200-day moving average and slumped 4% to a five-month low. Intuitive tumbled 8% Friday as worries over weakness in Europe and slowing prostatectomies in the U.S. offset better-than-expected Q2 results.

Starbucks (SBUX) cut its 5% loss to just 1% in modestly above-average volume. Starbucks' early swoon found support at the 200-day line. Rival Peet's Coffee & Tea (PEET) agreed to be bought by Germany's Joh. A. Benckiser for $977.6 million.
Starbucks will report fiscal Q3 earnings Thursday. The coffee giant's earnings are expected to grow 25% to 45 cents a share. If achieved, that would mark the second straight period of acceleration.

Stratasys (SSYS) pared a 7% loss to 1% in below-average trade. The stock broke out from a cup-with-handle base Wednesday in huge volume. Despite recent volatility, it's still 2% past a 54.47 buy point. Stratasys makes 3D prototyping systems for the aerospace, automotive, industrial and other markets.

Leaders up in volume were few. Monster Beverage (MNST) reversed early losses and rose 2% in above-average volume. Monster has sold off hard in the past two sessions after a Seeking Alpha article criticized its valuation.

Rentech Nitrogen (RNF) fell 4% in modestly above-average volume. Rentech could not regain its 28.91 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The November IPO broke out July 5 and climbed as much as 8% before losing steam.
Former leader Baidu (BIDU) fell 3% in the regular session, but was rising in late trade after the Chinese Internet giant released its Q2 results.

Meanwhile, the Nasdaq rose 1.8%, the NYSE composite 1.3% and the S&P 500 1.1%. Monster and Priceline tumbled on…
Stocks leaned lower out of the starting gate Friday, despite an early raft of strong economic data.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each dimmed 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average backed down 0.3%.
Volume was mild to lower, up 1% on the NYSE and down 8% on the Nasdaq, compared to trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today appeared to ignore positive retail sales and import/export price data for August, followed by a jump in consumer sentiment for September. A preliminary estimate put the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index at 84.6, up from 82.5 for August, easily above economist forecasts for 83.4 and the best number since July 2013.

In stocks, online ad agency Conversant (CNVR) soared 31% after Alliance Data Systems (ADS) announced late Thursday it would buy the company for $2.3 billion. The announcement said the deal should close by the end of the year. Alliance shares rose 4%.

Among leaders, China-based Autohome (ATHM) stepped up more than 2%, the biggest gain on the IBD 50 list. The stock was still trading down 4% so far for the week, in a three-week pullback from an Aug. 26 high.

Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) dropped 2% after Credit Suisse initiated coverage on the stock. Their note set a price target of 139, 7% below Thursday's closing level. Earnings reports drove the bulk of premarket action Thursday, as stock futures edged higher for the first time this week.Dow futures reversed early losses to gain 58 points. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 13.75 points and S&P 500 futures pulled out of the red to add 11 points.Weekly unemployment data was mildly positive, with claims down slightly, to 367,000, the Labor Department reported, vs. 368,000 claims in the prior week. Analysts expected 365,000 new claims. Ongoing claims continued to fall off, slowing to 3.229 million compared to 3.290 million a week earlier. Analysts forecast 3.288 million.The trade gap widened to $51.89 billion in March, vs. February's $45.4 billion. The number was just below January's $52.5 billion gap, the widest since October 2008, according to the Census Bureau. The strengthening of export prices slowed to 0.2%, down from a 0.5% gain in February.Steel maker ArcelorMittal (MT) forged ahead 2% in premarket trade. The Netherlands-based heavyweight earned a penny per share in the first quarter, four cents below expectations. Revenue rose 2% to just below consensus forecasts. The company said it expected steel shipments to hold steady and profitability to increase in Q2.Internet gear maker Cisco Systems (CSCO) took a beating, down 7% in premarket trade, after reporting results late Wednesday. The restructuring tech pioneer earned 48 cents per share on an adjusted basis, a 14% increase and a penny above analyst projections. Revenue rose 7% to $11.6 billion, also better than expected. The company guided second-quarter earnings to between 44 cents and 46 cents. Analysts wanted EPS of 49 cents. Cisco also guided Q2 revenue below forecasts.Priceline.com (PCLN) pared losses after slipping 3% ahead of the open. It reported late Wednesday it earned $4.28 per share on an adjusted basis in the first quarter, 30 cents above analyst consensus views. A 28% jump in revenue, to $1.04 billion, just met expectations.The online travel broker guided second quarter EPS to between $7.20 and $7.40 a share, to the low end of analyst forecasts. It projected Q2 revenue growth of 18% to $23% vs. views for 26%.Priceline.com has tested 10-week support twice since notching a new high April 13. It is the stock's first consolidation since clearing a 549.10 buy point in February.Other leaders also were active in the premarket, with IBD 50 stock Monster Beverage (MNST) up 13% after topping analysts' earnings and revenue forecasts for Q1. The energy drink maker, which sees about a fifth of sales from outside the U.S., said it planned launches in new international markets during the year.The stock pulled back in strong trade this week to test support at its 50-day moving average. The stock's chart is slightly distorted by the April 30 spike to 83.96 on rumors that Coca-Cola (KO) was set to acquire the company. Coca-Cola issued a statement denying it was discussing an acquisition.Overseas markets were relatively calm. Asia's major indexes closed narrowly mixed and stocks across Europe faced modest selling pressure heading into afternoon trade. Oil futures rose slightly, remaining just below $87 a barrel. Gold traded off a fraction, between the $1,590 and $1,600 an ounce marks. Natural gas continued its attempts to press past the $2.50 per million British thermal units level.

In a bid to boost already strong profits, Dunkin' Group (DNKN) is adding some pop and juice to its donuts and ice cream stores via a deal with soft-drink giant Coca-Cola (KO). The parent of the Dunkin' Donuts donut and coffee chain and Baskin-Robbins ice cream shops and its exclusive supplier, DCP, have entered into a multiyear marketing agreement with…

Coca-Cola Co. (KO) is expected to report a rise in first-quarter profit and revenue on April 17 despite increasing commodity costs and declining American demand for sugary soft drinks. The world's largest soft-drink company is expected to report a 1.2% rise in profit to 87 cents per share, ending three quarters of double-digit EPS growth. Sales are expected to lift…
Better-than-expected economic reports at home and China, along with successful debt auctions in Europe, lifted stocks Tuesday. But they ended off the best levels of the session.

The Nasdaq gained 0.6% and the S&P 500 rose 0.4%. They had been up as much as 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Dow rose 0.5%, with 23 of its components closing higher. Caterpillar (CAT), IBM (IBM) and United Technologies (UTX) were the biggest point gains. Volume rose on both major exchanges, according to unconfirmed figures.

Whole Foods Market (WFM) jumped 4% to a near-record high in more than twice its average volume. The stock cleared a 74.55 buy point from an 11-week cup-without-handle base. Despite Tuesday's move, the organic grocer's growth has waned in the past four quarters, from 65% to 27%. Analysts expect an 18% increase in earnings for Whole Food's December-ended quarter.

Monster Beverage (MNST) gapped up and rallied 4% to a new high in more than double its average volume. Goldman Sachs upgraded shares to buy from neutral and placed a price target at 124. Monster Beverage cleared a 98.46 buy point in flat base.

On the downside, Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) reversed course and tumbled 7% to a nine-month low. A Food & Drug Administration study found that a drug developed by Watson and Columbia Laboratories did not reduce the risk of premature birth. Volume swelled to more than six-times average.

Nuance Communications (NUAN) reversed from a new high and dropped 2% in heavy trading. The stock snapped a five-session win streak, but remained 11% past a 25.92 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Nuance develops speech and imaging technologies. Its earnings growth accelerated in the past two quarters. Analysts see further acceleration in the current period.
Charles Schwab (SCHW), eBay (EBAY), F5 Networks (FFIV), Fastenal (FAST), Goldman Sachs (GS), State Street (STT) and Xilinx (XLNX) will report earnings Wednesday.

Monster Beverage cleared a 98.46 buy point in flat base.On the downside, Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) reversed course and tumbled 7% to a nine-month low. A Food & Drug Administration study found that a drug developed by Watson and Columbia Laboratories did not reduce the risk of premature birth. Volume swelled to more than six-times average.Nuance Communications (NUAN) reversed from a new high and dropped 2% in heavy trading. The stock snapped a five-session win streak, but remained 11% past a 25.92 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Nuance develops speech and imaging technologies. Its earnings growth accelerated in the past two quarters. Analysts see further acceleration in the current period.Charles Schwab (SCHW), eBay (EBAY), F5 Networks (FFIV), Fastenal (FAST), Goldman Sachs (GS), State Street (STT) and Xilinx (XLNX) will report earnings Wednesday.Data on producer prices, capacity utilization, industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out Wednesday.
Stocks turned mixed late Friday afternoon, with the Dow Jones industrial average hitting resistance at the 13,000 mark, amid mixed economic data.

The Nasdaq was up 0.4%, but the S&P 500 was flat and the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.4% after again trying and failing to push above 13,000. Volume was lower on both the Nasdaq and NYSE, compared with the same time Thursday.

Drug shares were among the biggest gainers, led by IBD 50 stock Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR), which climbed 4% in high turnover and retook its 50-day moving average. The stock has risen steadily this week after the company reported better-than-expected Q4 earnings.
Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP) also rose 4% in strong trade and cleared its 50-day line, after Q4 profit rose a greater-than-expected 34% vs. a year ago on a 57% gain in revenue.

Friday's economic data were consistent with slow but steady growth. New-home sales dipped by 3,000 in January to an annual rate of 321,000, the Commerce Department said. But it was better than the expected rate of 315,000 sales.

Meanwhile, the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index climbed 2.8 points in February to 75.3, a one-year high and above expectations for 73. The index has advanced steadily since October.

IBD 50 consumer-related stocks fared well. Shares of Monster Beverage (MNST), down 5% in after-hours trading Thursday following weak Q4 results, rallied 1% in healthy trade on Friday after UBS raised its price target to 65 from 62.50 on strong international sales growth.
Apple (AAPL) rose 1% as it continued to recoup losses last week, when the stock suffered a bearish reversal after hitting a record-high 526.29. The stock is 22% past a 427.85 cup-with-handle entry.
MasterCard (MA) and online travel site Priceline.com (PCLN) also rose. Both are extended beyond their buy points.
Chinese online travel agency Ctrip.com International (CTRP) rose 5%, climbing back above its 50-day line. The stock remains a laggard, though, at 50% below a 52-week high.
Salesforce.com (CRM) jumped 10% in massive volume after a strong Q4 earnings report. The stock is forming the right side of a long, deep base and is now less than 10% below a 52-week peak of 160.12.

MercadoLibre (MELI) erased pre-market losses and rose 1% in powerful trade. The Argentina-based online auction and retail site tumbled 6% in after-hours action Thursday after reporting Q4 earnings rose 31% to 47 cents a share — 4 cents below analyst views. Revenue rose 39% to $85.6 million, also just below expectations.
Analysts said that foreign exchange swings hurt results but that underlying growth is strong.
Friday's move put the stock 7% above a 91.55 buy point after clearing a cup-with-handle base Feb. 2.

Global oil distributor World Fuel Services (INT) was the biggest loser in the IBD 50, crashing 11% and sinking below its 50-day line, as margins continued to contract and Q4 revenue missed analysts' forecasts. Stocks started out the holiday-shortened week with a show of strength, but lost much of their punch by Tuesday's close. The Nasdaq and NYSE composite added 0.6% and 0.5%, respectively, after each index traded as much as 1.2% higher. The S&P 500 tacked on 0.4%, pulling back from a 1.1% gain. Volume increased from Friday's level on the Nasdaq, but…

Several IBD 50 stocks staged breakouts during the past week, as the market's uptrend picked up more steam.Even so, a few leading stocks faltered, most notably Google (GOOG), which fell out of the IBD 50.F5 Networks (FFIV), Monster Beverage (MNST) and Steven Madden (SHOO) were among the leaders executing breakouts.F5 cleared a 117.40 buy point Thursday following its quarterly earnings report. The stock closed Friday about 2% beyond that ideal entry, leaving it in a possible buying range.Monster, formerly called Hansen Natural, topped a 98.46 trigger Tuesday, energized by a Goldman Sachs upgrade. It now stands more than 5% past that level, or outside a proper buy zone.Steven Madden popped above a 39.52 buy point Thursday, but closed a little under 39.52 for the week. On Friday, the shoemaker said it will buy its privately held Canadian licensee for $29 million, forecasting the deal will add 5 to 7 cents to its 2012 EPS.Another IBD 50 stock that acted well was SolarWinds (SWI), which jumped 7% for the week.The provider of IT management software has climbed above its 10-week moving average and seems to have formed the right side of a new base.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) tried to lift past a possible handle buy point at 427.85 on Wednesday, but turnover was soft. It ended the week below that level, with volume coming in above average Friday as the tech giant lost 2%.Apple, which has enjoyed a huge advance since 2009, plans to report its quarterly results Tuesday.Google (GOOG) lost 6% for the week, hurt by its disappointing quarterly report issued late Thursday. The stock dropped below its 10-week moving average and under a recent 599.70 handle buy point.Also on the downside, Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) shed 3% for the week, losing ground after its quarterly report late Thursday. Still, the robotic surgical gear maker managed to pare some losses and close above its 10-week line.IBD 50 stocks on average rose 1.2% during the holiday-shortened week, underperforming the main indexes. The Nasdaq advanced 2.8%, the NYSE composite 2.6% and the S&P 500 2%.

Stocks rallied into the close to finish with mild gains Monday, as the market stabilized after Friday's sell-off. The Nasdaq rose 0.4%, helped by Apple's  (AAPL) 4% gain ahead of its media event Tuesday. The tech-laden index lifted off support around 3000, a level that served as a floor in mid-August. The S&P 500 and NYSE composite each edged…

Stocks climbed in early trade Tuesday, boosted by earnings reports, healthy manufacturing data and a rally in overseas markets. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average each climbed 0.9%. The S&P 500 added 0.7%. Volume was tracking 12% stronger on the Nasdaq and up 23% on the NYSE compared with the same time Friday. United Technologies (UTX)grabbed a 3%…

The second-quarter earnings season is winding down, with most beating it as usual, though many have been light on revenue. But a bevy of elite IBD 50 stocks are on deck for this week, with fertilizer firm CF Industries (CF) and crude-oil pipeliner Plains All American Pipelines (PAA) kicking off the week, followed by an aerospace parts supplier, Transdigm Group[ticker…

Few top-rated stocks were making new highs on Monday. On the Nasdaq, only 10 hit highs vs. 86 striking lows. On the NYSE, new highs trailed lows, 65-87. B&G Foods (BGS), which was featured in Monday's Income Investor column, was one of the few winners. The stock jumped 3% in 47% faster turnover. B&G notched a 52-week high and cleared…

Double filtration helps remove remaining impurities from water or other liquids. In the same way, investors can use multiple screens to weed out less-than-stellar stocks to come up with a watch list of superior stocks across a wide range of criteria.

IBD's daily Screen of the Day is Big Cap Leaders, focusing on large capitalization stocks with superior fundamentals and other factors. This article will focus on the top 5 companies, which boast a best-possible 99 Composite Rating. All five also are members of the elite IBD 50, which culls the very best stocks of any size. Most report earnings next week.

Apple (AAPL) is the world's largest publicly traded company. Despite its massive size, it has continued to generate tremendous growth as it releases wave upon wave of innovative tech products, include the iPhone and iPad. Apple is rated No. 4 in the latest IBD 50.

Apple reports fiscal third-quarter earnings on April 24. Analysts expect a 33% earnings per share gain vs. a year earlier. That would be a big slowdown from the prior quarter's 92% gain and 116% in the prior quarter. Apple has a history of crushing Wall Street forecasts.

Apple shares sold off from early April to mid-late May, only briefly interrupted by a post-earnings spike. But over the last two months, Apple's stock has rebounded. It's been forming a handle in recent sessions.
Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) in late April announced plans to buy Swiss-based Actavis, which will make it the world's No. 3 generic drug maker.
No. 30 in the latest IBD 50, Watson reports earnings on July 26. Per-share profit likely climbed 38%, analysts say, following a 84% advance in the prior quarter.

Watson shares spiked higher in late April on the Actavis deal news. But with the market weak, the stock gave up those gains over the next several weeks. But since mid-June, Watson has worked on the right side of a base. The stock hit new highs on Monday and Tuesday.

Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) generates all its revenue from Soliris, which treats two types of rare blood diseases. But that hasn't limited Alexion's profits. The biotech is expected to report a 28% earnings per share rise on July 25. EPS grew 55% in the prior quarter.
Alexion is No. 3 in the IBD 50. Its shares jumped on July 2, then retreated over the next six sessions. They've recouped some of those losses in the last four sessions.

DaVita (DVA) operates kidney dialysis centers across the country. With diabetes rates soaring and the population aging, the demand for dialysis will remain strong. DaVita, No. 21 in the IBD 50, reports earnings on Aug. 1. Analysts are predicting a 26% rise following a 52% bounce in the prior quarter.
DaVita shares have risen strongly since the end of May. After a brief consolidation in early July, the stock has moved up again, hitting a new high Tuesday.

Monster Beverage (MNST) is a leader in the turbo-charged energy drinks market, via the Monster and Rock Star brands. Monster has benefitted from its distribution deal with Coca-Cola (KO). Monster shares briefly skyrocketed on April 30 on rumors that Coke would try to buy the company out. But that was part of a steady uptrend that lasted until mid-June. Shares have retreated since, closing below their 50-day moving average on Tuesday.
Monster earnings likely jumped 38% in the latest quarter, barely decelerating from the prior quarter's 41%.

Most Sector Leaders stocks rose Tuesday, but Sourcefire (FIRE) sank after announcing that its chief executive is taking a medical leave of absence. Volume was mostly lower in a shortened pre-holiday session. The leaders' list shrank by one, to 14, after Monster Beverage (MNST) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) were removed, replaced by software developer SolarWinds (SWI). Monster has tested…

Stocks regained on Friday a chunk of the ground they lost Thursday, but still finished mostly lower for the week. The Nasdaq rose 1.2%, the S&P 500 gained 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.5%. Each index sliced below its 50-day moving average Thursday and was unable to regain it Friday. Volume increased on both main exchanges, boosted…
Stocks regained on Friday a chunk of the ground they lost Thursday, but volume shows that investors were more eager to unload than they were to buy back.
The Nasdaq rose 1.2%, the S&P 500 recouped 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%. Each index sliced below its 50-day moving average Thursday and was unable to regain it Friday.
Volume fell 16% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, according to preliminary data.
For the week, the Nasdaq rose 0.6%, the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the Dow dropped 0.9%.

IHS (IHS) jumped 4% in huge turnover. Late Thursday, the market researcher said a secondary public offering of 8.7 million shares was priced by an existing stockholder, Conscientia Investment, at 100 per share.

Earlier this week, IHS reported second-quarter EPS and sales that beat expectations, but it guided 2012 EPS below forecasts. In recent weeks, the stock has been consolidating in a choppy fashion in the vicinity of its 10-week moving average. IHS has an IBD Composite Rating of 94 out of a best-possible 99.

On the downside, Monster Beverage (MNST) fell 1.5% in strong volume after climbing out of the gate. Late Thursday, Standard & Poor's said the energy drinks maker will replace Sara Lee (SLE) in the S&P 500 effective June 28. Monster, No. 13 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup, remains well above a flat base buy point of 48.75.

On the earnings front, Darden Restaurants (DRI) slid 1% in heavy turnover after it reported quarterly profit that matched forecasts and revenue that missed expectations. The operator of Olive Garden and Red Lobster restaurants is trading below its 50-day moving average and has been consolidating for about five weeks. Darden has an 81 IBD Composite Rating.
Align Technology (ALGN) recouped virtually all of an early 4% dive. But the orthodontics maker couldn't regain its 33 buy point from a double-bottom base. Align is No. 5 in the IBD 50.

Some of the big banks fared well despite downgrades by Moody's. JP Morgan (JPM) rose 2% and Morgan Stanley (MS) gained 1%. Even Credit Suisse (CS), which was downgraded three notches, managed to climb 1%.Stocks regained on Friday a chunk of the ground they lost Thursday, but volume shows that investors were more eager to unload than they were to buy back.The Nasdaq rose 1.2%, the S&P 500 recouped 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6%. Stock futures backed out of early losses and into narrow gains ahead of Friday's open.

Dow futures were 5 points above fair market value, up from a 6-point decline an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures reversed to trade up 9.7 points. S&P 500 futures showed a 2.2-point gain. Small caps remained under pressure, with Russell 2000 futures off earlier lows, but still trading down 3 points.

The stock market today launches into July's last trading session with the S&P 500 up 2.2% for the month and the Nasdaq ahead 2.9% — not resounding gains, but the best month for both indexes since the market stumbled into its dull, narrow trading range in March.

The Nasdaq heads into Friday's session toting a 0.8% gain for the week. The S&P 500 is up 1.4%. The Dow is up 1%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 managed to regain their 50-day lines this week, continuing the back-and-forth dance for support. Distribution — a gauge of institutional selling — eased a bit during the week, relieving at least some pressure on the struggling uptrend. But the tightly rangebound markets are sending no clear signals on where things are headed next, and while many leading stocks are performing well, investors should maintain a cautious stance.

The Labor Department's Employment Cost Index rose at a slower rate in the second quarter, up 0.2%, vs. a 0.7% gain in Q1. The increase was well below estimates for a 0.6% increase and reportedly at the slowest quarterly rate in 27 years.
Kingsbury International reports its July Chicago Purchasing Managers Index at 9:45 a.m. ET. The University of Michigan releases its final tally on July consumer sentiment at 10 a.m.

The earnings calendar set some big names in motion ahead of the open. Amgen (AMGN) rose nearly 3% on strong Q2 results. Honda Motor (HMC) also gained 3%. Steel titan Arcelor-Mittal (MT) climbed nearly 2%. Exxon Mobil (XOM) dipped 2%.

At the smaller end of the spectrum, Prince George, Utah-based Skywest (SKYW) spired 18% before the open after clearing Q2 earnings expectations by a wide margin. Revenue slipped less than forecast, and the company said $30 million of its current $505 million cash tally would go toward new jets scheduled for delivery from Embraer (ERJ) in Q3 and Q4 this year. The stock has been consolidating and struggling to hold support at its 10-week moving average, below a mid-May high.

Coca-Cola Enterprises (CCE) surged 10% in premarket trade. News reports said the Atlanta-based producer of soda in European markets was engaged in discussions with peers in Spain and Germany about a deal that would streamline bottling operations. The company also reported Thursday its Q2 earnings topped expectations by a narrow margin. Revenue fell 17%, slightly less than expected.

Expedia (EXPE) sparked an 8% gain after reporting late Thursday its second-quarter earnings fell less, revenue rose more than forecast by analyst consensus. The online travel broker also reported a jump in room nights as well as gross bookings. The stock ended Thursday 7% below a 115.10 buy point in a flat base.

Touch pad maker Synaptics (SYNA) dived 11% after earnings missed and revenue just met projections in its fiscal fourth quarter. The stock had pulled back from a mid-June high to end Thursday in a test of support at its 40-week moving average,

Hanesbrands (HBI), king of the tightie whities, dropped nearly 8% before the bell. Earnings just met expectations, revenue didn't for the second quarter, and management lowered its full-year revenue guidance to below consensus views. The stock ended Thursday above its 10-week line and in a cup-with-handle base.

LinkedIn (LNKD) dumped 7% after an apparently healthy Q2 report late Thursday. Adjusted earnings surpassed consensus earnings and revenue estimates by wide margins, and management raised its Q3 and full-year guidance above consensus views, but a big GAAP loss due in part to its purchase of Lynda.com and a decline in display ads may have fanned investor fears. Shares have been consolidating, fighting to regain key levels of support following a May selloff.

Overseas, China's markets posted a mixed finish to the week. The Shanghai Composite dipped 1.1% to take a 1% loss for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose 0.6% Friday, leaving it down 1.9% for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 edged up 0.3% to end the week essentially unchanged.

In Europe, leading indexes were narrowly mixed near midday Friday. The CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were tacking toward flat finishes for the week. London's FTSE 100 traded 1.2% above last Friday's close.

The dollar was mixed, down vs. the euro, up against the yen and trading slightly lower vs. the euro for the week. Bonds edged a fraction lower and were effectively flat for the week. Oil dipped, with West Texas Intermediate down nearly 2% to below $48 a barrel and tracking 1% lower for the week. Europe's Brent crude benchmark dipped more than 1%, trading at $52.65, down 3.6% vs. last Friday's settle price.
