Nearly all Sector Leaders ended higher Friday, but volume was weak in almost all of them. One day after staging a downside reversal, Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) put in an upside reversal. It climbed 1.78, or 3%, to 70.88. The stock regained its 50-day moving average, which acted as resistance in recent sessions. But volume tumbled 43% below average, showing that…

Sector-leading stocks gave back all or most of their early gains Wednesday. Volume was mostly lower, which dulled the negative edge. However, negative reversals aren't what bulls want to see, especially in a market correction that has sagged for more than a month. And many sector-leaders closed low in the day's range, which is another negative sign. The biggest percentage…

New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg's proposed ban on the sale of sodas over 16 ounces in restaurants and movie theaters drew a terse response from Coca-Cola (KO) Thursday, but did little to affect the company's stock or that of Pepsico (PEP). Meanwhile, Bloomberg's role in the upcoming National Donut Day is being questioned.Coke and Pepsi shares closed down 0.4% and 0.5%, respectively. Dr Pepper Snapple Group (DPS) shares were up 0.4%.Bloomberg's proposal would remove super-sized and even large sized sugary soft drinks from menus across the city in an effort to help curb rising obesity rates. The ban won't affect the sale of large drinks in grocery stores or the sale of diet beverages and drinks with less than 25 calories per 8 ounces. Milkshakes and any drink made with half milk or a milk substitute would also be exempt.Coca-Cola said in a statement on its website that it hopes New Yorkers loudly voice their disapproval about what it called an arbitrary mandate."The people of New York City are much smarter than the New York City Health Department believes. We are transparent with our consumers," the statement said. "They can see exactly how many calories are in every beverage we serve. We have prominently placed calorie counts on the front of our bottles and cans and in New York City, restaurants already post the calorie content of all their offerings and portion sizes - including soft drinks."Coca-Cola's statement said New Yorkers expect and deserve better, and can make their own choices about what drinks to buy."The city is not going to address the obesity issue by attacking soda because soda is not driving the obesity rates," said Stefan Friedman, spokesman for the New York City Beverage Association in an AP article.American's have long been losing their taste for the sweet carbonated beverages as soft drink consumption has declined steadily since 2005. In 2011 the total sales volume of carbonated beverages dropped nearly 1% to 9.27 billion cases, according to Beverage Digest, an industry newsletter.Sluggish soda sales have prompted McDonald's (MCD) to offer fancy coffee drinks like mocha lattes to compete with Starbucks (SBUX). But the switch to coffee might not help lagging beverage sales as sugary coffee drinks would fall under the ban. However lattes and cappuccinos of any size that contain at least 51% milk would be allowed.Starbucks opened an Evolution Fresh juice shop in Washington state earlier this year to branch out from its coffee roots. The juice will also be available in Starbucks coffee shops across the U.S. Beverages that contain at least 70% juice will not be affected by the NYC drink ban.Energy drink makers like Monster Beverage (MNST) sell their beverages in large 16 ounce cans and won't be affected with the ruling. But sales could be impacted if the ban lowered the size of the drinks banned to 15 ounces or less. McDonald's and Starbucks shares fell fractionally Thursday. Monster lost 1.4%.Bloomberg's proposal only needs approval of the Board of Health — which seems likely to approve the measure — but public hearings will also be held.Separately Thursday, Entenmann's Bakery issued a press release for the 75th National Donut Day, which is Friday. It planned a "sweet celebration" at New York's Madison Square Park and said it would "share a Proclamation letter from Mayor Bloomberg." Also at the event: free donuts, and the unveiling of "the largest box of Entenmann's Donuts ever created along with custom-made donuts 1-foot in diameter."

Sector Leaders battled to a mixed finish amid choppy market conditions Thursday. Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) gapped up and gained 2.05, or 3%, to 72.76 in roughly average volume. Wells Fargo raised the drugmaker to outperform from market perform and lifted its earnings estimate. Last month, Watson Pharmaceuticals agreed to buy Actavis Group to create the world's third-largest generic drug company.…

Stocks waved a caution flag Monday as they dropped moderately and snapped a four-session winning streak. The Nasdaq shed 0.7%, while the S&P 500 and NYSE composite both fell 0.4%. Volume increased from Friday's level on the NYSE, handing a distribution day to both the NYSE (1) and the S&P 500 (2). Volume decreased on the Nasdaq. It's discouraging to…

The stock indexes showed virtually no hesitation Thursday as they tacked on moderate gains. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each rose 0.7%, and the NYSE composite added 0.6%. Volume fell on the NYSE and rose on the Nasdaq. The NYSE composite regained its 50-day moving average. The other indexes climbed above that key level Wednesday. Economic news Thursday was mixed.…
Stock futures swung lower in a morning of erratic trade, with earnings reports driving the bulk of the action.
Dow futures were down 69 points and continuing to lose ground. S&P 500 futures were off 6.1 points and Nasdaq 100 futures slipped 4.25 points.

Growing strength in export prices stalled in October, the Labor Department reported, with prices flat vs. September's 0.8% advance, the weakest performance since June. Rising import prices decelerated for a third straight month, up 0.5% vs. a 1.1% gain in September.
Monster Beverage (MNST) tanked 10%, then rebounded to a fraction loss. Whole Foods Market (WFM) recovered to a slim gain after trading 4% lower in early action.

Shares of online travel deal aggregator Kayak Software (KYAK) soared 26% ahead of the bell. Priceline (PCLN) announced late Thursday it would buy the Norwalk, Conn.-based company for $1.8 billion (Priceline also is based in Norwalk). Kayak also reported better-than-expected earnings after the close. Priceline shares traded down 2% in premarket action.

Groupon (GRPN) tanked 17% after third-quarter earnings met expectations but revenue growth of 32% stopped short of its own guidance. The company took a hard hit from low sales in Europe, despite growing in the U.S. The company cut about 950 employees during the quarter, including 500 sales personnel.

Strayer Education (STRA) booked an 8% premarket loss. The Virginia-based for-profit educator reported EPS down 70%, not as bad as the 73% drop feared by analysts. Revenue slipped 9%, also less than expected. But the company guided Q4 earnings to well below consensus forecasts. It also suspended its dividend and said bad dept had climbed 40 basis points during the quarter.
Revamped retailer JC Penney (JCP) dived 7% after reporting earnings and sales declines far worse than anticipated by analysts. Same-store sales slumped 26% vs. the 17% drop forecast by analysts.

Walt Disney (DIS) traded down 5% after delivering weak Q3 results late Thursday. Third-quarter earnings rose 15%, revenue crept up 3%, both stopping short of analyst targets. The stock has been in a tight consolidation since late September, fighting to retake support at its 50-day moving average since Oct. 23.

Leading stocks mulled in tame trade. Randgold Resources (GOLD) dropped 3%, the largest move among IBD 50 stocks. Bank Of America downgraded the stock to neutral from buy on Thursday, citing disappointing third-quarter results as well as possible mining code revisions and unrest in Mali.
Shares have pulled back for five weeks, undercutting a prior buy point at 119.83 and cutting support at the 50-day line in heavy trade on Tuesday.
Overseas, Asia's markets ended with mild losses Friday, but down sharply for the week. For the week, the Shanghai Composite fell 3%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 retreated 3.2%.
Europe's markets at midday showed uneven losses, with Frankfurt's DAX down hardest at -1%. Major indexes were tracking toward losses in the 2% to 3% range for the week.

The dollar climbed to a two-month high vs. the euro, while slipping to a three-week low against the yen. Oil dipped to just below $85 a barrel, but was essentially flat so far for the week. Gold inched above $1,729 an ounce, gunning for a weekly gain of 3% or better.

The University of Michigan plans to release November Consumer Sentiment numbers at 9:55 a.m. EST. Stocks remained higher early Friday afternoon as rising consumer confidence offset a decline in new-home sales and a rise in oil prices.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each added 0.4% in weak trade. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.2%, also in lower volume.

Drug shares were among the biggest gainers, led by IBD 50 stock Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR), which climbed 6% in high turnover and retook its 50-day moving average. The stock has risen steadily this week after the company reported better-than-expected Q4 earnings.
Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP) rose 5% in strong trade, also clearing its 50-day line, after Q4 profit rose a greater-than-expected 34% vs. a year ago on a 57% gain in revenue.

Friday's economic data was consistent with slow but steady growth. The Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index climbed 2.8 points in February to 75.3, a one-year high and above expectations of 73. The index has advanced steadily since October.

IBD 50 consumer-related stocks fared well. Shares of Monster Beverage (MNST), down 5% in after-hours trading Thursday following weak Q4 results, rebounded 2% on Friday after UBS raised its price target to 65 from 62.50 on strong international sales growth.
Meanwhile, new-home sales dipped by 3,000 in January to an annual rate of 321,000, the Commerce Department said. But it was better than the expected rate of 315,000 sales.
Chinese online travel agency Ctrip.com International (CTRP) rose 3%, climbing back above its 50-day line. The stock remains a laggard, though, at 50% below a 52-week high.
Salesforce.com (CRM) jumped 9% in massive volume after a strong Q4 earnings report. The stock is forming the right side of a long, deep base and is now less than 10% below a 52-week peak of 160.12.

MercadoLibre (MELI) erased pre-market losses and rose 3% in powerful trade. The Argentina-based online auction and retail site tumbled 6% in after-hours action Thursday after reporting Q4 earnings rose 31% to 47 cents a share — 4 cents below analyst views. Revenue rose 39% to $85.6 million, also just below expectations.
Analysts said that foreign exchange swings hurt results but that underlying growth is strong.
Friday's move put the stock 9% above a 91.55 buy point after clearing a cup-with-handle base Feb. 2.

On the downside, global oil distributor World Fuel Services (INT) crashed 9%, sinking below its 50-day line, as margins continued to contract and Q4 revenue missed analysts' forecasts. Even the launch of more flavorful diet sodas has failed to stem the tide as U.S. consumption of soft drinks fell to 1996…

Stocks sustained modest losses Wednesday, as the Nasdaq fared worst with a 0.5% decline. The S&P 500 dipped 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.2%. Volume decreased across the board from Tuesday's levels, according to early data, taking some of the punch out of the losses. After hours, Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) fell as it reported first-quarter profit that…

Stocks sold off Tuesday on news of some disappointing earnings with the Dow taking the brunt of the damage. The Dow Jones industrial average slid 1.8%. The bad news there came from DuPont (DD), which swooned 9%, and 3M (MMM), which sank 4%. Both logged fast trade. But the roster of blue chips was riddled with chunky declines. The Nasdaq…

Energy drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST) stock plunged about 10% during the trading day Friday, as of midafternoon. The company disclosed late Thursday that a state attorney general is investigating its namesake drink line, and other energy drink makers were thought to have also received subpoenas.
Monster, which on Wednesday reported quarterly results below analysts' estimates, said an unspecified state's AG was probing the ingredients in Monster Energy drinks and its advertising practices.

Other energy drink makers got similar subpoenas, according to analysts cited in a Reuters report, which said officials at Red Bull, 5-Hour Energy, Rockstar, Coca-Cola (KO) and PepsiCo (PEP) were not immediately available to comment.

Monster said in its Securities and Exchange Commission filing that in July, it got a state attorney general's subpoena: "in connection with an investigation concerning the Company's advertising, marketing, promotion, ingredients, usage and sale of its Monster Energy brand of energy drinks."
Monster's SEC filing said the investigation is at an early stage and "it is unknown what, if any, action the state attorney general may take."
Dr. Pepper Snapple Group (DPS), maker of the Venom brand energy drink, said it had not received any subpoena. Its shares edged up slightly in Friday trading.
Shares of Coca-Cola, which makes Burn, were off 0.7% and those of PepsiCo, maker of Amp energy drink, edged down 0.1%.

Monster's earnings per share rose 31% in its second quarter vs. the same quarter last year, but that was 2 cents below Wall Street estimates. Sales of $592.6 million also came in lighter than expected.
The maker of energy drinks, juices and other beverages is the top-rated company in the Beverages-Non-Alcoholic group, ranked a strong No. 30 of the 197 industry groups IBD tracks.

Among other highly rated beverage makers in the group, Coca Cola Femsa (KOF), the Mexican Coke bottling company, edged up 0.3%. And National Beverage Corp. (FIZZ), which sells soft drinks, juices and bottled water under Shasta, Crystal Bay and other brands, slipped 0.6%.

Coffee stocks have been moving too, after a weak report on July 26 by Starbucks (SBUX). The coffeehouse giant has rallied in the last week, though, and Friday afternoon, shares were up 0.9%. Rival Peets (PEET) edged down 0.1% and smaller Caribou Coffee (CBOU) fell 2.6%.Energy drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST) stock plunged about 10% during the trading day Friday, as of midafternoon. Action was sleepy among sector leaders Monday as volume fell. The list itself has an anemic look. In Monday's edition, the top six sectors — which include utility, media, alcohol-tobacco, building and food-beverage — did not host a single leadership-quality stock. Last week stocks such as energy drink maker Monster Beverage (MNST) and online travel arranger Priceline.com (PCLN) fell out…
Stocks opened narrowly higher Thursday after after a decent weekly jobs report trumped weak June inventories data.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.2% gain. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1% each. Volume tracked 12% higher on the Nasdaq and 12% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Wednesday.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.2% in June, according to the Census Bureau. That was the first decline this year and below expectations for a 0.3% increase.

At the high end of the market, perfume and skin care products brand Elizabeth Arden (RDEN) jumped 21% on strong fiscal fourth quarter results. Oil and gas fracking equipment specialist Robbins & Myers (RBN) leapt 27% after agreeing to a $2.5 billion buyout offer from National Oilwell Varco (NOV).
Monster Beverage (MNST) held down the low end, dropping 7% after a weak Q2 report.

Network gear leader Cisco Systems (CSCO) climbed 3% at the open, the largest gain on the Nasdaq 100 and the Dow. Goldman Sachs added the stock to its conviction buy list, citing strong networking and capital expenditure plans among North American companies. The stock has been working to climb off the floor of a long consolidation.

Randgold Resources (GOLD), also a Nasdaq 100 stock, rose 3% after reporting strong results for the first half of the year. The stock has been rising off a mid-May low, is above its 10-week line and just below its 40-week moving average.

Advanced Auto Parts (AAP) slumped 4% after reporting second-quarter sales and earnings below the consensus projection. The stock had been struggling to retake its 10-week line after correcting 35% since April.

Action among stocks in IBD's Sector Leaders was constructive for the week, with more showing complete bases and more joining leadership status. The number of stocks listed as Sector Leaders increased to 16 from 12 for the week, as technical factors improved across the group. Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) saw its Accumulation-Distribution Rating improve to a D+ from an E. Watson…
Battered consumers have made dollar stores and other discounters prime investment plays these days.

Dollar Tree (DLTR) keeps customers stocked with basic food and housewares, all priced at a buck or less. Family Dollar (FDO) serves a similar niche with offerings under $10. Ross Stores (ROST) keeps budget-conscious shoppers clothed in name-brand outfits.

The three are on IBD's Screen of the Day measuring bolting relative strength lines. The RS line measures a stock's price against the broader S&P 500. When it's climbing during a broad rally, you've found a market leader. In a market correction like now, the RS line can climb even as the stock moves sideways. Such resilience shows names that could lead the next rally.

Dollar Tree shares climbed 2% Monday to 101.99 — though its lowest-possible Accumulation/Distribution Rating of E suggests selling by big institutions. Family Dollar was up 1% at 67.83, with Ross up less than 1% at 61.96.

Another discounter holding its own is Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), though it doesn't make the screen. Its shares have risen sharply to long-time highs after the world's No. 1 retailer reported better-than-expected Q1 results on May 17.

Dollar General (DG), which posted better-than-expected earnings Monday, is also near new highs, though it doesn't make the screen either. Dollar General shares fell in late trading Monday on so-so guidance and plans for a big secondary share offering.

But discounters aren't alone on the Bolting RS Lines screen. Aerospace supplier TransDigm (TDG) has boosted sales in large part on the growth of orders for commercial jet giants Boeing (BA) and Airbus.
Monster Beverage (MNST), the energy drink maker which has become the pick-me-up of choice for young 20-somethings at convenience stores, rose 3.6% to 73.11 on Monday.
Expedia (EXPE) exploded in late April on strong quarterly results. The online travel site has continued to trend higher, rising 0.6% on Monday to 44.93.

Another unlikely hotshot is Nationstar Mortgage (NSM). Stocks notched a solid open Tuesday, with tech and transportation stocks leading and energy and mining issues bringing up the rear.
The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%. The S&P 500 added 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on a 0.3% gain.
Volume was briskly mixed in the stock market today, up 28% on the Nasdaq and down 20% on the NYSE, the inverse of early trading action on Monday.

Air transport issues, led by FedEx (FDX) and United Parcel Service (UPS), notched the best early gains among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Gold, coal and oil groups posted the five worst losses on the list.
The Commerce Department reported construction spending surged 1.1% in October. That reversed a revised 0.1% decline for September and easily outpaced economist expectations for a 0.5% increase.

Early stock action showedBiogen (BIIB) skipping up 5% after the company reported positive results from a phase 1b study of its Alzheimer's Treatment, and plans to aggressively move into a phase 3 trial. The gain lifted shares back above their converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, but left the stock still within a three-month consolidation.

Cypress Semiconductor (CY) powered up 17% and punched to a 16-month high after agreeing to be acquired by Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Spansion (CODE) in an all-stock deal valued at $4 billion. Cypress shares have been wallowing in a consolidation since mid-2013. Spansion shares fired ahead 24%, well into new highs.
Among leaders, Ambarella (AMBA) and Celgene (CELG) jumped to the front of the IBD list.

Ambarella popped 3% at the start of trade, retaking a portion of its 8% tumble taken on Monday. The video chip maker is trading 9% below Friday's high, and extended after a strong October rebound from 10-week support.

Biotech drug maker Celgene climbed nearly 2%, moving to a new high and now 20% above a 96.60 buy point from a double-bottom base.Stocks notched a solid open Tuesday, with tech and transportation stocks leading and energy and mining issues bringing up the rear.The Nasdaq climbed 0.5%. The S&P 500 added 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on a 0.3% gain.Volume was briskly mixed in the stock market today, up 28% on the Nasdaq and down 20% on the NYSE, the inverse of early trading action on Monday.Air transport issues, led by FedEx (FDX) and United Parcel Service (UPS), notched the best early gains among the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Gold, coal and oil groups posted the five worst losses on the list.The Commerce Department reported construction spending surged 1.1% in October. That reversed a revised 0.1% decline for September and easily outpaced economist expectations for a 0.5% increase.Early stock action showedBiogen (BIIB) skipping up 5% after the company reported positive results from a phase 1b study of its Alzheimer's Treatment, and plans to aggressively move into a phase 3 trial. The gain lifted shares back above their converged 10- and 40-week moving averages, but left the stock still within a three-month consolidation.Cypress Semiconductor (CY) powered up 17% and punched to a 16-month high after agreeing to be acquired by Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Spansion (CODE) in an all-stock deal valued at $4 billion. Cypress shares have been wallowing in a consolidation since mid-2013. The recent market swoon has shaved about $74 billion off Apple's  (AAPL) market capitalization since early April, but it's still a hefty $520.8 billion and doesn't look likely to collapse anytime soon. Other companies on the latest Big Cap Leaders screen also aren't as big as they once were, but like Apple they retain basic strengths that helped them…

Thursday earnings: Latin American e-commerce powerhouse MercadoLibre said after the close that it earned 47 cents a share up 31% vs a year earlier but 4 cents below analyst forecasts. Revenue rose 39% to $86.5 million, slightly below forecasts. MercadoLibre raised its quarterly dividend by 36% to 10.9 cents a share. But shares tumbled 6% in early after hours trading. They sank 0.7% to 97 in Thursday's regular session.But shortly after Friday's market open, MercadoLibre were up more than 4% to 101.26, back at record highs. Analysts noted foreign exchange swings hurt results, but stressed that underlying growth is strong.Monster Beverage earned 35 cents a share, up 32% vs. a split-adjusted 26.5 cents a year earlier but a penny below Wall Street estimates. Sales grew 29% to $410 million, just below views of $410 million. Shares of the energy drink maker fell 5% in early after-hours trading, reversed to move 2% higher, before moving slightly lower. The stock fell 19 cents to 54.87 in the regular session.But shortly after the market open, Monster Beverage shares were up 3% to 56.45. UBS raised its price target to $65 from $62.50, citing international growth and other opportunities for gains.***Wednesday earnings: Discounters Dollar Tree and TJX Cos. report before Wednesday's opening bell, continuing the week's run of major and often top-performing retailers.Specialty discounter Dollar Tree reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter profit and sales, but gave somewhat cautious guidance for the current first quarter. The company's earnings per share rose 24% to $1.60. Revenue climbed 13% to $1.95 billion. Analysts expected EPS of $1.58 on sales of $1.93 billion. Same-store sales increased 7.3% while store square footage rose 6.9% vs. a year earlier. Operating margins rose on higher gross margins and lower operating costs.For Q1 Dollar Tree expects to earn 91-97 cents a share on revenue of $1.65 billion-$1.69 billion. That assumes low- to mid-single-digit same-store sales growth. But it's slightly below Wall Street forecasts for EPS of 98 cents and revenue of nearly $1.70 billion.Dollar Tree shares fell 0.7% on Wednesday, off from session lows. The stock hit a new high intraday Tuesday, but closed down 1.5%TJX Cos. reported a 17% EPS gain to 62 cents as revenue rose 6% to $6.71 billion. Analysts expected a 62-cent gain and sales of $6.725 billion. Same-store sales rose 7%. TJX's Q1 EPS forecast for 45-47 cents is in line with Wall Street forecasts. That assumes 2%-4% same-store sales growth.The retailer hiked its quarterly dividend by 21% to 11.5 cents a share.TJX shares closed down 0.3%.After Wednesday's close, highly rated Limited Brands reported Q4 results, but the Victoria's Secret parent's Q1 guidance sent shares lower in late trading. But Limited  was fractionally higher Thursday afternoon.Also after Wednesday's close, IBD 50's Concho Resources and Questcor Pharmaceuticals reported results. Questcor reported adjusted Q4 EPS of 47 cents, up 292%, on revenue of $75.5 million, up 158%. That beat Wall Street views for EPS of 42 cents and  revenue of $72.8 million. Shares shot up 8% in Thursday afternoon trading.Concho earned $1.15 a share adjusted, up 53% vs. a year earlier but

missing views for $1.19. Revenue rose 48% to $478.4 million, above views for $451.79 million. Shares fell more than 5% in Thursday afternoon trading.***Tuesday update: Steven Madden kicked off IBD 50 earnings results Tuesday morning, reporting earnings per share of 55 cents, up 34% vs. a year earlier and 1 cent above analyst estimates. Revenue shot up 74% to $279.8 million, as its larger wholesale business to other retailers nearly doubled. Sales at its retail operations rose nearly 19% to $53.8 million, with same-store sales up 15.9%.The shoe and accessories designer, wholesaler and retailer said earnings sees this year's profit of $2.60-$2.70 vs. analyst views of $2.69 million. It sees revenue climbing 21%-23%, or roughly $1.18 billion, vs. the consensus of about $1.20 billion.Steven Madden shares fell 2.4% to 42.20.After Tuesday's close, Herbalife reported earnings per share of 86 cents, up 30% vs. a year earlier and 13 cents above Wall Street forecasts. Revenue jumped 20% to $884.6 mil, significantly above analyst estimates. Asian and Latin American growth led the way.The direct seller of nutritional products sees Q1 EPS of 76-80 cents and raised its full-year 2012 EPS target to $3.40-$3.60. Both bracket Wall Street estimates.The company also raised its quarterly dividend to 30 cents a share from 20 cents.Herbalife shares rose nearly 6% in early after-hours trading. During the regular session, the stock climbed about 3% to 62.46, breaking out of a recent consolidation.Herbalife holds a post-earnings conference call on Wednesday morning.*** Posted 2/18/2012 10:05 AM ETEarnings season may be winding down, but not for leading stocks. At least eight companies from the IBD 50 list report quarterly results this week. Most are consumer-related.Tuesday, Feb. 21Herbalife (HLF)Herbalife sells nutritional products worldwide via a massive direct sales force. Asia accounts for most of its growth.Fourth-quarter earnings likely rose 11% to 73 cents a share, analysts say. Sales probably rose 16% to $856.6 million.Shares are near the top of a consolidation going back to early August.Steven Madden (SHOO)The fashion and accessories shoe designer, marketer and retailer should turn out a blowout Q4. Analysts see earnings climbing 32% to 54 cents a share. They expect sales to jump 65.3% to $266.20 million. That would be the ninth quarter in a row of double-digit sales and profit growth.Madden markets products under its own brands, such as Steve Madden and Betsey Johnson.Steven Madden has 84 retail stores, but its wholesale business is much larger. It distributes its products to various retailers, including department stores and specialty chains.Steven Madden shares hit a new high last week.Madden is one of 12 major retailers reporting earnings this week — including the very biggest. Two other IBD 50 retailers report on Wednesday.Wednesday, Feb. 22Concho Resources (CXO)Concho is a domestic energy producer, specializing in the Permian Basin straddling Texas and New Mexico. In Q3, oil accounted for 73% of sales and natural gas 27%.Analysts expect Concho to report a 59% earnings per share gain to $1.19. Revenue likely rose 40% to $451.8 million.With oil prices rising above $100 a barrel last week, Concho shares hit a new high intraday on Friday.Dollar Tree (DLTR)Analysts see its earnings rising 22.5% vs. a year ago to $1.58 a share. They forecast a 12% sales gain to $1.9 billion. That would be Dollar Tree's 12th straight quarter of double-digit sales and profit growth.The specialty discounter sells everything for $1 or less. But its shares are up 547% from the January 2008 low, hitting a fresh high on Friday.Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR)The drugmaker pre-announced on Feb. 3 that H.P. Acthar Gel sales were $75 million in Q4. Questcor also said it expects to report operating income of $41 million to $43 million. Both were better than analysts expected.Shares popped on that day, but then resumed their decline from their Dec. 9 record high. The stock is approaching its 200-day moving average.TJX Cos. (TJX)The owner of the T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and Home Goods chains offers brand-name products at discounts of 20%-60%. Analysts expect TJX Cos. to report a 17% EPS gain to 62 cents. Sales likely grew 11% to $6.72 billion.TJX shares have been steadily climbing for months, rising 2% on Friday to a new high.In addition to Dollar Tree and TJX, highly rated (but not-quite IBD 50) Limited Brands (LTD) reports earnings Wednesday. It operates the Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works chains.Thursday, Feb. 23MercadoLibre (MELI)The Argentina-based Internet firm often is called "Latin America's eBay (EBAY)." The company offers a buying and selling platform in Argentina, Brazil, Mexico and more. Internet use in the region is surging from low levels.Analysts see MercadoLibre reporting a 42% EPS gain, with Q4 revenue up 41% to $87.7 million.Shares broke out to a new high on Wednesday, but pulled back the next two sessions.Monster Beverage (MNST)Formerly known as Hansen Natural, the beverage maker changed its name to reflect the importance of its caffeine-spiked energy drink, which is 90% of total sales. Natural sodas, juices and iced teas make up the rest.The U.S. energy drink market remains strong in the U.S., and Monster keeps pushing into more parts of Europe. Its main rival is Red Bull.Monster's Q4 earnings rose 33% to 36 cents a share, analysts predict. Revenue likely climbed 29% to $411 million.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @EdCarson1.

Stock futures steered toward a strong opening Friday, tracking gains overseas after European leaders exited a two-day summit on a positive note. Dow futures swept ahead 184 points. Nasdaq 100 futures traded up 47 points and S&P 500 futures jumped 24.7 points. It's the last trading day of the second quarter, and quarterly options expirations are likely to drive above-average…

Top-rated industries offer more fertile hunting grounds for great stocks. But some winners hide in the rough in languishing sectors.Here's a look at the top five firms by Composite Rating in sectors residing among the bottom quarter of IBD's 197 industry groups. All are part of the elite IBD 50 for superior fundamental and technical factors.1. Liquidity Services (LQDT)Through sites such as Liquidation.com, Govliquidation.com and Govdeals.com, this online marketplace helps governments, businesses and private individuals buy and sell surplus and salvage goods. The company, with a high-flying Composite Rating of 97, resides in the Retail-Internet group, ranked 192 this week. Just six months ago it was flying near the top, at No. 4.Shares of Liquidity Services, which is No. 6 on the IBD 50 list, touched an all-time high Tuesday, before easing back to close at 46.30.Meanwhile, MercadoLibre (MELI), often referred to as the eBay (EBAY) of Latin America, is part of the same lagging industry group, and ranks only a bit lower with a Composite Rating of 91. Its shares also closed near an all-time high at 97.29. It's No. 40 on the IBD 50.2. Spirit Airlines (SAVE)This discount airline is another high-flyer in an industry — Transportation-Airline — that's nearly skidded off the runway at No. 171 among IBD industry groups. Spirit, No. 14 on the IBD 50 list, has a solid 96 Composite Rating. The Florida-based airline provides no-frills travel to Latin America and the Caribbean, with fares as low as $9.It came public last may at 12, and closed Tuesday at 19.32.3. Monster Beverage (MNST)Energy drinks and other beverages have been surging, while soft drink sales continued to fizzle in 2011, new data out Tuesday show. Monster, which started out as Hansen Natural, and still makes Hansen's Natural Soda and other beverages under that brand. But its No. 1 seller is Monster Energy, that high-caffeine jolt of energy in a can.The company, No. 19 on the IBD 50 list, owns a high-flying 96 Composite Rating, despite residing in a Beverages-Non-Alcoholic group that ranks a lowly 155. But its energy drinks are growing fast while U.S. sales of carbonated beverages from Coca-Cola (KO), PepsiCo (PEP) and others have fallen to their lowest levels since 1996.Monster shares sit near an all-time high at 60.44.4. NetEase.com (NTES)The Chinese online game company has been the exclusive Chinese operator of the wildly popular "World of Warcraft" game franchise since 2009. It launched the third installment of that game, "Cataclysm," last July. Revenue from that blockbuster, made by U.S.-based Activision Blizzard (ATVI) slowed in the fourth quarter. But the company said its internally developed games are building a loyal following. NetEase and Activision agreed to a three-year contract extension late Tuesday.NetEase, No. 48 on the IBD 50 list, has a Composite Rating of 95. But the Computer Software-Gaming group ranks No. 154 out of 197. Shares closed near an all-time high of 56.30.5. Steven Madden (SHOO)The trendy shoe and accessory designer sells its Steve Madden and other brand shoes at top department stores and retailers. It also operates its 83 stores as well as its Web site. Sales at its own shops open at least a year climbed 15.9% in the fourth quarter.Steven Madden, at No. 43 on the IBD 50 list, sports a strong Composite Rating of 94. But its group, the Apparel-Shoes & Related Manufacturing sits low at No. 173.The world's largest athletic shoe maker, Nike (NKE), resides in the same group, and wears a slightly lower 90 Composite Rating.

Pharmacy benefits management firm Express Scripts (ESRX) said its $29 billion acquisition of rival Medco Health Solutions delivered savings faster than expected, helping drive better-than-expected Q2 results.
And the company said its impasse with drugstore chain Walgreen (WAG) — which it settled last month — didn't hurt it much.
That news helped boost Express Scripts shares more than 9% for the week, and helped elevate it to the elite IBD 50 list at No. 29.
It was one of nine firms promoted to the list published in Monday's Investor's Business Daily.
The consulting and IT market research firm Gartner (IT) joined at No. 38. For-profit university Grand Canyon Education (LOPE) joined at No. 41.
Danish drugmaker Novo Nordisk (NVO) is No. 43. Fertilizer maker Agrium (AGU) moved to No. 44. Business intelligence firm IHS (IHS) moved to No. 45.
Network testing equipment maker IXIA (XXIA) is No. 46. Disk drive maker Seagate Technology (STX) moved to No. 47. And fertilizer maker Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) moved to No. 48.
Nine others fell off to make room.
One of them was Monster Beverage (MNST), the energy drink maker that disclosed late Thursday it was being investigated by a state attorney general about its ingredients, advertising and other issues.
The online travel agency Priceline.com (PCLN) also slipped off. Its shares tumbled 15% for the week, after it gave weak guidance on economic head winds from Europe and currency effects.

The others off the list were cosmetics retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA), farm supplier Tractor Supply (TSCO), bakery-cafe chain Panera Bread (PNRA), freight hauler Union Pacific (UNP), discount flier Spirit Airlines (SAVE), oil mover and storer Plains All American Pipeline (PAA) and network security firm Fortinet (FTNT).Pharmacy benefits management firm Express Scripts (ESRX) said its $29 billion acquisition of rival Medco Health Solutions delivered savings faster than expected, helping drive better-than-expected Q2 results.And the company said its impasse with drugstore chain Walgreen (WAG) — which it settled last month — didn't hurt it much.That news helped boost Express Scripts shares more than 9% for the week, and helped elevate it to the elite IBD 50 list at No. 29.It was one of nine firms promoted to the list published in Monday's Investor's Business Daily.The consulting and IT market research firm Gartner (IT) joined at No. 38. The $570 million Nuveen Large Cap Growth Opportunities is a top echelon portfolio, seeking to resume its winning ways after having hit a rough patch in 2011.

The fund's average annual gain of 14.60% in the three years going into Thursday ranked in the top 16% of its large-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. But in calendar 2011 its 2.69% loss meant it trailed 56% of its peers.
This year the fund is up 9.81% vs. 9.15% for its category and 10.69% for the S&P 500.
Hal Goldstein, 53 years old, is co-lead manager with Scott Mullinix. James Diedrich is co-manager. Goldstein discussed his approach from his office in Minneapolis.
IBD: What are you doing differently this year?

Goldstein: We were challenged particularly in the fourth quarter. There was a rapid turn toward stocks that benefit from an economic recovery — lower-quality, more cyclical names. And that's the environment in which we do least well.
Our year was sort of respectable. We were in the middle of the pack.
IBD: And this year?

Goldstein: We won't do anything differently. We stay true to our process. There are occasions when our approach, like in Q4, is completely out of favor. But even when we underperform in a tough quarter, our long-term performance remained strong.
IBD: Have you fished for bargains?

Goldstein: Yes. Some of our favorite growth companies' earnings prospects have stayed strong while their valuations have been compressed. So we've added to or repurchased names after not having owned them for a bit.
IBD: Such as?

Goldstein: Citrix Systems (CTXS). They're involved in desktop virtualization. Much like the way that VMware (VMW), a provider of software behind virtualization servers, helps client enterprises with efficiency and cost reductions, Citrix lets enterprises purchase less powerful desktop computers for employees and manage the software more centrally. It's much less expensive than maintaining software on each desktop.

We sold Citrix last year because we felt the cycle for desktop virtualization was advancing at a slower pace than anticipated. The growth thesis was not coming true. But even when we sell a company, we keep monitoring it. It may get to a point where we want to buy it back. And since then we've seen more evidence that desktop virtualization is advancing, so we added it back.
IBD: What's another example?

Goldstein: Amazon (AMZN). We added to our holding this year. The reason is that while it has not been controversial that revenue growth has been strong, we believe Amazon is gaining share within online sales while at the same time online is gaining share from bricks-and-mortars.

Many investors were concerned that Amazon's profitability was permanently impaired as it made significant infrastructure investments and as its shipping costs as a percent of sales have gone up quite a bit.
We believe in Q1 there were signs that margins were at least stabilizing and perhaps showing early signs of improving.
IBD: Where is the bargain bin aspect?

Goldstein: It's hard to argue that Amazon is super cheap. But we felt it was attractively valued as growth continued and margins stabilized or improved. For example, shipping costs as a percent of sales declined for the first time in three years.
But, yes, we did add more stable companies because of the challenging economic environment.
IBD: Some examples, please.

Goldstein: In the consumer space, PetSmart (PETM). They have merchandizing initiatives that will allow for accelerating growth within each store. Same-store comps should improve. It's already happening to some degree. So there's an earnings upside surprise opportunity as well. If sales are better than expectations, that can lead profits above expectations.
In health care, Idexx Laboratories (IDXX) provides veterinary lab testing products. They benefit from the rising trend of pet adoptions.

We think rising pet adoptions is a sign of the economy being a little better. Employment trends are a little better. Housing is bottoming or improving. Residential rental activity is up. More people are moving out of their parents' homes and starting households.
IBD: In general, what's your approach?

Goldstein: First, we buy a subset of a highly selective universe of what we call exceptional growth companies. The subset is those companies for which our expectations most exceed consensus expectations.
Second, we develop a proprietary growth thesis for each holding.
We hold each investment for the vast majority of its opportunity. When that opportunity no longer exists, we sell. It's critically important to sell when it is appropriate.
One last thing we do is construct a balanced portfolio. Our objective is to dampen volatility.
IBD: You do that through diversification, right?
Goldstein: Yes. We diversify by sectors, by market capitalizations and by style.
IBD: What is style diversification?
Goldstein: We have cyclical growth names, more stable growth names and high growth companies.
We don't own many companies domiciled outside the U.S. But we have a meaningful number of holdings that have revenue exposure outside the U.S.

One way we don't diversify is by relative weighting. We don't allow ourselves to have more than 10 percentage points more or less than a sector's weighting in the Russell 1000 Growth Index. We're typically closer to the benchmark weighting than that.
And we allow ourselves as much as a 300 basis points overweight on any individual security. Again, in practice our largest overweights tend to average about 200 basis points.
IBD: Does your diversification within sectors reflect your style diversification?
Goldstein: Right. Our health care holdings, for example, are not all of the same type.

We own Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), a fast-growing, high-multiple pharmaceutical company. The company is involved with ultrarare disease pharmaceuticals. We also own Gilead Sciences (GILD), which is involved with hepatitis C vaccines. And we own Vertex (VRTX), which is also involved with hepatitis C, but whose next opportunity is (the drug Kalydeco for) treatment of cystic fibrosis. Those biotech companies are developing tomorrow's cures.
Also, we own Perrigo (PRGO), which is a more stable company that is the leading maker of store-brand over-the-counter medicines.
IBD: Describe your diversification within another sector, such as consumer discretionary, please.

Goldstein: On the one hand we own Dollar Tree (DLTR) and TJX Cos. (TJX). Of course they benefit from the reality that more people are economically challenged and are trading down to dollar stores and discount stores.
On the other hand, we own Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Coach (COH). Both of those are focused on a much higher-end demographic, more of a luxury end.
IBD: How does this approach show up in your largest sector, technology, with 33% of your assets?
Goldstein: On the one hand we have Apple (AAPL). Like Lululemon it is gaining meaningful, profitable market share and tends to sell higher priced products to a more affluent demographic.

On the other hand we own Accenture (ACN), which is a consulting and outsourcing company, which serves global Fortune 100 companies. Apple is consumer focused. Accenture is enterprise focused, helping clients cut costs.

We also have Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA), which fall into the tech sector but aren't tech per se. But they do use a lot of technology in what they do. They're really about increasing the use of plastic globally as a method of payment. There's terrific profitability that accrues to Visa and MasterCard. The more that people swipe cards, the incremental costs to Visa and MasterCard are way below their incremental revenues. It's a terrific margin opportunity.
IBD: Apple's recent quarterly earnings report disappointed. Do you see a long-term problem?

Goldstein: We don't believe it's a sign of any long-term crack. Our thesis is that they will gain profitable global market share in consumer electronics. When we first bought Apple, all it meant was Mac computers. Now they have mobile phones, and a new category they invented, tablets. All of that is still intact.

One reason there was a pause (in Apple stock performance) is that many consumers are waiting for the next iteration of the iPhone before updating. I'm one of them. Pent-up demand for the iPhone 5 is large, not only among existing iPhone users but also among consumers who don't own an iPhone. So it's a temporary pause (in sales) before a bigger ramp-up later this year and next year.
IBD: Teradata (TDC) has four quarters of 25% or higher earnings per share growth. What's your thesis?

Goldstein: They benefit from the proliferation of data. They sell hard and software combinations that let very large enterprises collect and analyze large amounts of data, which in turn they use to make strategic decisions.
Demand for data analytics and their other services is very strong. So we love their top-line growth. We look for companies with top-line growth, not just margin improvement.
IBD: Netsuite's (N) EPS growth jumped to 100% and 200% the past two quarters. What's your take?
Goldstein: This is one of our emerging high growth, high valuation companies.

They're in software-as-a-service, so it's a cloud play. Like Salesforce.com (CRM) they benefit from enterprises that want to get business-critical software through cloud delivery. It's software on a buy-as-you-need-it basis, rather than owning an old-fashioned in-house suite of software.
IBD: Is Cerner's (CERN) story basically the shift to electronic health care records?

Goldstein: Cerner is one of the leading public companies in health care information technology. They have a strong backlog, whether it's due to government regulatory changes or merely a reflection of economics encouraging hospitals to automate and digitize. This is a really well run, leading health care IT company.
IBD: Monster Beverage (MNST) has two quarters of accelerating EPS growth. What's your view?

Goldstein: Monster has done well and is still attractive. They are gaining share within the energy drink market. Their international opportunities are sizable. As they mature internationally, there's a nice margin improvement opportunity as well. We own it for reasons other than it might get purchased by, for example, Coke (KO). But we're not betting on that.
IBD: Whole Foods (WFM) has exploded off its recession trough. How much more can this specialty market grow?

Goldstein: We believe there is still a lot of room to run. Their same-store sales in a tough economy suggest they deliver what American consumers want. Comps were up 8% (in fiscal Q3). The rise in store-level operating margins shows great discipline. We expect they will continue to grow their store base. Combined with same-store growth, you get meaningful profit growth.
IBD: GNC's (GNC) EPS growth has slowed for two quarters. Do they need a shot of Geritol?
Goldstein: In the most recent quarter, same-store sales were up almost 13%, which is higher than most retailers.
Secondly, their opportunity to grow internationally attracts us.

We think earnings estimates will rise the rest of this year and most of next year. Collectively, all of those factors point to an attractive opportunity.The $570 million Nuveen Large Cap Growth Opportunities is a top echelon portfolio, seeking to resume its winning ways after having hit a rough patch in 2011.The fund's average annual gain of 14.60% in the three years going into Thursday ranked in the top 16% of its large-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. The growth thesis was not coming true. But even when we sell a company, we keep monitoring it. It may get to a point where we want to buy it back. The reason is that while it has not been controversial that revenue growth has been strong, we believe Amazon is gaining share within online sales while at the same time online is gaining share from bricks-and-mortars.Many investors were concerned that Amazon's profitability was permanently impaired as it made significant infrastructure investments and as its shipping costs as a percent of sales have gone up quite a bit.We believe in Q1 there were signs that margins were at least stabilizing and perhaps showing early signs of improving.IBD: Where is the bargain bin aspect?Goldstein: It's hard to argue that Amazon is super cheap. But we felt it was attractively valued as growth continued and margins stabilized or improved. For example, shipping costs as a percent of sales declined for the first time in three years.But, yes, we did add more stable companies because of the challenging economic environment.IBD: Some examples, please.Goldstein: In the consumer space, PetSmart (PETM). They have merchandizing initiatives that will allow for accelerating growth within each store. Same-store comps should improve. It's already happening to some degree. So there's an earnings upside surprise opportunity as well. If sales are better than expectations, that can lead profits above expectations.In health care, Idexx Laboratories (IDXX) provides veterinary lab testing products. They benefit from the rising trend of pet adoptions.We think rising pet adoptions is a sign of the economy being a little better. Employment trends are a little better. Housing is bottoming or improving. Residential rental activity is up. More people are moving out of their parents' homes and starting households.IBD: In general, what's your approach?Goldstein: First, we buy a subset of a highly selective universe of what we call exceptional growth companies. The subset is those companies for which our expectations most exceed consensus expectations.Second, we develop a proprietary growth thesis for each holding.We hold each investment for the vast majority of its opportunity. When that opportunity no longer exists, we sell. It's critically important to sell when it is appropriate.One last thing we do is construct a balanced portfolio. Our objective is to dampen volatility.IBD: You do that through diversification, right?Goldstein: Yes. We diversify by sectors, by market capitalizations and by style.IBD: What is style diversification?Goldstein: We have cyclical growth names, more stable growth names and high growth companies.We don't own many companies domiciled outside the U.S. But we have a meaningful number of holdings that have revenue exposure outside the U.S.One way we don't diversify is by relative weighting. We don't allow ourselves to have more than 10 percentage points more or less than a sector's weighting in the Russell 1000 Growth Index. We're typically closer to the benchmark weighting than that.And we allow ourselves as much as a 300 basis points overweight on any individual security. Again, in practice our largest overweights tend to average about 200 basis points.IBD: Does your diversification within sectors reflect your style diversification?Goldstein: Right. Our health care holdings, for example, are not all of the same type.We own Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), a fast-growing, high-multiple pharmaceutical company. The company is involved with ultrarare disease pharmaceuticals. We also own Gilead Sciences (GILD), which is involved with hepatitis C vaccines. And we own Vertex (VRTX), which is also involved with hepatitis C, but whose next opportunity is (the drug Kalydeco for) treatment of cystic fibrosis. Those biotech companies are developing tomorrow's cures.Also, we own Perrigo (PRGO), which is a more stable company that is the leading maker of store-brand over-the-counter medicines.IBD: Describe your diversification within another sector, such as consumer discretionary, please.Goldstein: On the one hand we own Dollar Tree (DLTR) and TJX Cos. (TJX). Of course they benefit from the reality that more people are economically challenged and are trading down to dollar stores and discount stores.On the other hand, we own Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Coach (COH). Both of those are focused on a much higher-end demographic, more of a luxury end.IBD: How does this approach show up in your largest sector, technology, with 33% of your assets?Goldstein: On the one hand we have Apple (AAPL). Like Lululemon it is gaining meaningful, profitable market share and tends to sell higher priced products to a more affluent demographic.On the other hand we own Accenture (ACN), which is a consulting and outsourcing company, which serves global Fortune 100 companies. Apple is consumer focused. Accenture is enterprise focused, helping clients cut costs.We also have Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA), which fall into the tech sector but aren't tech per se. But they do use a lot of technology in what they do. They're really about increasing the use of plastic globally as a method of payment. There's terrific profitability that accrues to Visa and MasterCard. The more that people swipe cards, the incremental costs to Visa and MasterCard are way below their incremental revenues. It's a terrific margin opportunity.IBD: Apple's recent quarterly earnings report disappointed. Do you see a long-term problem?Goldstein: We don't believe it's a sign of any long-term crack. Our thesis is that they will gain profitable global market share in consumer electronics. When we first bought Apple, all it meant was Mac computers. Now they have mobile phones, and a new category they invented, tablets. All of that is still intact.One reason there was a pause (in Apple stock performance) is that many consumers are waiting for the next iteration of the iPhone before updating. I'm one of them. Pent-up demand for the iPhone 5 is large, not only among existing iPhone users but also among consumers who don't own an iPhone. So it's a temporary pause (in sales) before a bigger ramp-up later this year and next year.IBD: Teradata (TDC) has four quarters of 25% or higher earnings per share growth. What's your thesis?Goldstein: They benefit from the proliferation of data. They sell hard and software combinations that let very large enterprises collect and analyze large amounts of data, which in turn they use to make strategic decisions.Demand for data analytics and their other services is very strong. So we love their top-line growth. We look for companies with top-line growth, not just margin improvement.IBD: Netsuite's (N) EPS growth jumped to 100% and 200% the past two quarters. What's your take?Goldstein: This is one of our emerging high growth, high valuation companies.They're in software-as-a-service, so it's a cloud play. Like Salesforce.com (CRM) they benefit from enterprises that want to get business-critical software through cloud delivery. It's software on a buy-as-you-need-it basis, rather than owning an old-fashioned in-house suite of software.IBD: Is Cerner's (CERN) story basically the shift to electronic health care records?Goldstein: Cerner is one of the leading public companies in health care information technology. They have a strong backlog, whether it's due to government regulatory changes or merely a reflection of economics encouraging hospitals to automate and digitize. This is a really well run, leading health care IT company.IBD: Monster Beverage (MNST) has two quarters of accelerating EPS growth. What's your view?Goldstein: Monster has done well and is still attractive. They are gaining share within the energy drink market. Their international opportunities are sizable. As they mature internationally, there's a nice margin improvement opportunity as well. We own it for reasons other than it might get purchased by, for example, Coke (KO). But we're not betting on that.IBD: Whole Foods (WFM) has exploded off its recession trough. How much more can this specialty market grow?Goldstein: We believe there is still a lot of room to run. Their same-store sales in a tough economy suggest they deliver what American consumers want. Comps were up 8% (in fiscal Q3). The rise in store-level operating margins shows great discipline. We expect they will continue to grow their store base. Combined with same-store growth, you get meaningful profit growth.IBD: GNC's (GNC) EPS growth has slowed for two quarters. Do they need a shot of Geritol?Goldstein: In the most recent quarter, same-store sales were up almost 13%, which is higher than most retailers.Secondly, their opportunity to grow internationally attracts us.We think earnings estimates will rise the rest of this year and most of next year. Collectively, all of those factors point to an attractive opportunity.
Stocks turned negative in late trading Monday amid concerns about corporate profits, following a series of weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings reports.

The Nasdaq was down 0.1% while the S&P 500 was down 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.7%. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board compared with the same time Friday. Options expiration boosted Friday's trade.

Caterpillar (CAT) was up a fraction after Q3 profit and sales topped forecasts but the heavy equipment maker issued a weak outlook. The mixed report followed earnings misses last week at fellow bellwether stocks Google (GOOG), McDonald's (MCD) and General Electric (GE).
Metals and mining stocks were among the biggest gainers

Among IBD 50 stocks, VF Corp. (VFC) plunged 5% in massive trade, briefly piercing its 50-day line, after Q3 profit rose a greater-than-expected 23% from a year ago. However, sales rose just 14%, trailing expectations. The maker of clothing brands such as the North Face and Wrangler has fallen for three straight sessions in increasing volume.
Under Armour (UA), which makes athletic apparel, was down more than 2% in light turnover ahead of its Q3 earnings report Thursday.

Meanwhile, Monster Beverage (MNST) dived 10% in huge trade after the family of a 14-year-old who died after drinking its Monster Energy drink filed suit against the company for failing to warn about the beverage's dangers.
The stock has sunk further below its key support lines and is now 43% off its 52-week high.
Metals and mining companies were among the day's biggest gainers.

Canada-based Silver Wheaton (SLW), a buyer of silver and gold from mining companies, rose 2% in above-average volume as it tries to clear resistance at about 40. Meanwhile, Allied Nevada Gold Corp. (ANV) was up a fraction in above-average trade. It's struggling to break above a 40.03 buy point.Stocks turned negative in late trading Monday amid concerns about corporate profits, following a series of weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings reports.The Nasdaq was down 0.1% while the S&P 500 was down 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.7%. Shares of energy drinks and juices maker Monster Energy (MNST) plummeted on a report that it's being sued by the family of a girl who died after reportedly drinking a large can of its energy drink two days in a row.

The suit filed in California Superior Court in Riverside Monday by the family of 14-year-old Anais Fournier claims the company, which touts the ability of its drinks to boost energy levels, failed to adequately warn people about the product's dangers.
Fournier died Dec. 23, 2011, from caffeine toxicity after drinking a 24-ounce can of Monster Energy on two consecutive days, the suit said.
Shares of Monster, which earlier this year changed its name from Hansen's Natural, was down 14.2% at 45.73 in Monday afternoon trading.

Among other large nonalcoholic beverage companies, Coca-Cola (KO) and archrival PepsiCo (PEP) were both down less than 1%, as were Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) and Canada's Cott (COT), which sells under its namesake brand as well as Vintage, Carters and Ben Shaw.

In a filing last Friday related to the lawsuit against Monster on Monday, the family's law firm said six deaths and 15 hospitalizations associated with Monster Energy drinks had been reported to the FDA's Center for Food Safety Adverse Event Reporting System since 2009.

The New York Times (NYT) quoted an FDA spokeswoman in an interview as saying the agency had received reports of five deaths possibly linked to the drink as well as another report of a heart attack during the period from 2004 to June of this year.

Monster said it does not believe its drinks are "in any way responsible" for Fournier's death, and it intends to vigorously defend itself. "Monster is unaware of any fatality anywhere that has been caused by its drinks," the company said in a statement.
The claim is similar to ones lodged earlier against other energy drink makers, including privately held German energy drink maker Red Bull.

Red Bull was denied market approval in France nearly a decade ago when an 18-year-old Irish athlete died after reportedly consuming four Red Bull drinks in a short period of time. The company eventually won approval in France after the company challenged in the European Court of Justice in 2004.Shares of energy drinks and juices maker Monster Energy (MNST) plummeted on a report that it's being sued by the family of a girl who died after reportedly drinking a large can of its energy drink two days in a row.The suit filed in California Superior Court in Riverside Monday by the family of 14-year-old Anais Fournier claims the company, which touts the ability of its drinks to boost energy levels, failed to adequately warn people about the product's dangers.Fournier died Dec. 23, 2011, from caffeine toxicity after drinking a 24-ounce can of Monster Energy on two consecutive days, the suit said.Shares of Monster, which earlier this year changed its name from Hansen's Natural, was down 14.2% at 45.73 in Monday afternoon trading.Among other large nonalcoholic beverage companies, Coca-Cola (KO) and archrival PepsiCo (PEP) were both down less than 1%, as were Dr Pepper Snapple (DPS) and Canada's Cott (COT), which sells under its namesake brand as well as Vintage, Carters and Ben Shaw.In a filing last Friday related to the lawsuit against Monster on Monday, the family's law firm said six deaths and 15 hospitalizations associated with Monster Energy drinks had been reported to the FDA's Center for Food Safety Adverse Event Reporting System since 2009.The New York Times (NYT) quoted an FDA spokeswoman in an interview as saying the agency had received reports of five deaths possibly linked to the drink as well as another report of a heart attack during the period from 2004 to June of this year.Monster said it does not believe its drinks are "in any way responsible" for Fournier's death, and it intends to vigorously defend itself. With less than an hour to go, Monster Beverage Corp (MNST) is under stiff pressure of around 12%. The company disclosed last night a subpoena by the attorney general in connection with an investigation into its advertising, marketing, promotion, ingredients, usage and sale of its popular branded Monster Energy drink.

The action hasn't gone unnoticed by option traders as volume has swelled nearly nine-fold to 44,000 contracts. Spiking implieds and put contracts being the flavor of the day by a 1.3-to-1 margin suggests traders anticipate continued volatility in shares of MNST. ATM implieds in the August contract are pricing in a one standard deviation or 68% chance shares could see a move up or down of around 8.5% through next Friday based on today's shift in implieds to 62% from 38% last night.

Looking out into Monster's September options, implieds have risen by about 10 points from 39% to almost 49%. While the increase is smaller in absolute terms, vega or volatility risk per point for those call and put contracts is substantially larger at $0.07 versus August's $0.03. That said, the pricing also reflects a larger percentage move of more than 16.5% in shares during the next 42 calendar days until September comes off the board.

Last night's subpoena news follows Wednesday night's disappointing earnings miss. The combined price action has shares off about 21% for the two-day period, hitting five-plus month lows and now in bear territory below the 200-day simple moving average for the first time in a couple years. One idea for bearish traders wanting to greatly reduce volatility risk and keep any potential losses limited is the bear vertical.

With Monster's options fairly liquid, traders have more than a few both bear call and bear put verticals to consider ranging from spreads constructed as tight as 2.5 points, 5 points and even as wide as 7.5 points while still greatly reducing vega risk. Shown above is a -5x September 60 / 62.5 bear call spread. For a $0.50 credit, the spread can collect the full credit if at expiration shares remain below 60. Currently that buffer means the trader can have shares move about 10% higher and still take in the maximum profit.

Risk of $2.00 is the difference between strikes minus the credit. That amount would be realized if shares of MNST are above 62.5 at expiration or earlier, if by chance, past bubbly buzz of Monster being an acquisition target, was to reintroduce itself. And while losses are never fun, being able to keep them small and manageable in the face of what would amount to being a monster move, makes the vertical a sensible strategy.

IBD 50 constituent and beverage upstart Monster Beverage Corp (MNST) saw its shares explode higher intraday Monday after the Wall Street Journal reported the company could be in talks with the world's largest soft drink maker, Coca-Cola  (KO).

The massive and volatile price spike which saw shares almost touch $84 compared to Friday's close near $65.50 and pierce the $14.0 billion capitalization mark didn't go unnoticed by option traders and activity sporting a strong bias favoring calls by a three-to-one margin.

Overall demand for long call and protective put strategies sent front month implieds up towards 65% and a test of two year highs and the June contract into the low 50s. Compared to statistical volatility in the mid-20s to mid-30s, traders are pricing in further above-normal movement. The largest concentration of such demand is the June 80 calls, which were briefly in-the-money and now about 5% to 6% above the current share price.

A jump in implieds of about 50% from near 36% to the low 50s, coupled with the intraday surge in share price has resulted in the June 80 call having an ultra-wide trading range from a low of $0.20 to a high of $8.00. That said, with a current price of $3.50 and virtually no open interest; we also strongly suspect some of today's obvious opening activity has already done a fair bit of ultra-fast money closing and for better and also worse in a market that takes two to consummate the trade.

What do you think? Wall Street erased its losses in late afternoon trading Monday amid hopes that Germany would come to the aid of embattled eurozone countries. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were flat while the S&P 500 was up 0.1%. All three indexes were down as much as 0.8% earlier. Volume was 12% lower on the Nasdaq and 19% lower…

It seems appropriate to us, changing the name Hansen's Natural and the now defunct ticker "HANS" to Monster Beverage Corp (MNST) given the gargantuan stature of the company's muscular beverage product. But the change also seems a sign of the times given MNST's rather monster or enormous and bubbly-looking four-month long ascending base.

First off, let's caveat MNST's base by saying it is admittedly a slightly flawed formation. For one, the construction maintains basically four pivot highs rather than the classic three since construction began back in early August. Furthermore, the first pivot high, which we're classifying as occurring back on September 21, did subsequently see shares slide 19%. That's a bit more than the idealized maximum 15% dip to start off the first counter wave.

Other than those pesky details, which I'm almost certain are subject to revision by other prying eyes, the new and improved Hansen's i.e. Monster, still affords traders listed calls and puts to protect and maybe even juice up one's stock holdings.

The downside, as was the case with Hansen's, the name change hasn't improved its option's liquidity. Personally, we'd label those markets as only moderately yummy and good for either outrights and maybe two-sided spreads like a vertical, calendar or diagonal. That all said, while Monster's options aren't going to win flavor of the month anytime soon, they're good enough to consume in moderation without any adverse side effects.

What do you think? The S&P 500 retreated less than 0.2%. The IBD 50, a proxy for leading stocks, fell 0.2%. Volume was up ever so slightly on the…

While the S&P 500 toys with its own monster breakout around its October highs and the closely watched 1300 level, one name fittingly sporting a monster breakout to fresh all-time-highs is Monster Beverage Corp. (MNST).

The IBD 50 constituent was discussed last week in this column with a detailed eye on both its admittedly, slightly-flawed four month ascending base and listed calls and puts to "protect and maybe even juice up one's stock holdings."

With the breakout in place and Monster's options still only moderately delicious for either outrights and some two-sided spreads, one position idea we like to ensure keeping the trading account bubbly is a slightly out-of-the money February 105 / 110 bull call spread.

Priced for $1 late in Tuesday's session, using 2% portfolio risk on a model $20K account would allow for 4 verticals to be placed. This means the trader wouldn't need to worry about discretionary money management in order to keep any potential losses of the small and manageable variety. Not that we personally mind that idea, particularly so if shares fell below $96 and we were able to walk away with a loss closer to 1% of the max risk.

And on the upside, if during the next 30 calendar day's bulls continue to guzzle up shares, it would take less than 10% from today's idealized breakout of $98.46 to realize a return in excess of 100% on the initial investment. In seeing how the signal price was traded through with a bullish gap, the luxury of this type limited risk strategy which allows one to breathe a bit easier regarding any future minding of that gap; makes even better sense and cents of it all.

To cope with current sluggish GDP growth, some managers focus on high dividend yield stocks. Not Fidelity's Jason Weiner.
"I'm way more focused on the growth side of things," said the helmsman of $1.1 billion Growth Discovery Fund .
Sixteen of his 157 holdings were in the IBD 50 going into Tuesday. Six were on IBD's Leaderboard.
Even his stake in Apple (AAPL), which made a high-profile announcement in March about a share buyback program and resuming its dividend, is mainly for the sake of growth.
"Its yield is nothing to write home about," Weiner said. "But you're getting good growth at a modest P-E."
Its 1.8% yield is shy of the S&P 500 tech sector's 1.84% average. The entire S&P 500's dividend payers average 2.45%.
One key Apple driver is the iPhone 4S, which is on sale in more than 100 nations, including China.
Also unlike many competitors, Weiner didn't use the Q1 market sell-off to add to names he likes. Rather, he traded less.
"My playbook is the opposite," he said. "I'm trading less."

Even his interest in energy transportation master limited partnerships — Oneok Partners (OKS), Markwest Energy (MWE) and Atlas Pipeline (APL) as of his latest disclosure — is due to growth as well as income.
"It's a small corner of the fund, where dividend yields are growing fast," he said.
Weiner's tack had the fund up 16.40% this year going into Tuesday. The fund's large-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. averaged 14.91%. The S&P 500 gained 11.88%.
Over the past three years the fund's average annual gain was 22.55% vs. 18.81% for its peers and 19.46% for the big-cap bogey.
Racy Advertising
Monster Beverage (MNST) soared Monday before closing slightly down amid rumors of a Coke (KO) takeover.
Weiner said, "Monster uses racy advertising to sell to teenage boys and younger men. Their energy beverage is in a growing category."
Herbalife (HLF), a holding as of the fund's latest disclosure, plunged Tuesday on monster volume as its first-quarter profit topped estimates, but it forecast Q2 earnings below estimates.
Also, a short-seller from Greenlight Capital questioned the company about its 10-K SEC filing.
Last week Cirrus Logic (CRUS) reported Q1 EPS of 36 cents. That was up 64% over Q1 last year, and it beat estimates by 2 cents.
Despite issuing cautious guidance, the stock rose 30% last week. That put it 12% over its buy point in a cup-with-handle base. It's up 73% this year.
The firm is a major supplier to Apple.
Dollar General (DG) is up 15% this year. EPS growth has accelerated for three quarters. Return on equity has accelerated three years in a row.
Investors' concerns about economic weakness tend to help dollar chains.
On Tuesday, the Institute for Supply Management said U.S. manufacturing expanded at the fastest pace in 10 months in April.

But no worries. Dollar General is a proven model, Weiner says. "They can tweak their model, squeezing more profit from their stores," he said. "That's not an original idea.
